HEADLINE: Houses With Maple Trees: Beauty, Shade and, Sometimes, Syrup

BYLINE: As told to Seth Kugel

 BODY:

WHO -- Joseph S. Nye, 67, dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University; shown with Molly Nye, 64, art consultant
WHAT -- Moose Meadow Farm, a 4-bedroom house on a 770-acre tree farm
WHERE -- North Sandwich, N.H.
 We bought this house in 1991, It's an old center-chimney colonial that was built in 1822. We were looking for a place where we could enjoy our children and grandchildren, of which we now have eight.
 About eight years ago we got into backyard maple sugaring, as they call it here. We're tapping two maples right behind the house along with about a dozen other trees.
 We are producing two and a half to three gallons of syrup, which sounds like a little, but that's 100 to 120 gallons of sap. The ratio is 40 to 1.
 The sap starts flowing around the end of February, beginning of March. You drill about a one-inch hole into the tree and you hammer in a little spout and hang buckets under those spouts. You collect the sap and boil it down. Then you filter it, put it in a jar, seal it and it's good for delicious waffles and pancakes for the rest of the year.
 You don't do it for the economics. It's therapy. Right now the snow is beginning to melt, but we won't see daffodils and forsythia for another six weeks. It gives you a feeling of new life and resurgence and spring well before you'll ever see spring.
 We have a friend, the president of a major university, who comes up to ski with us, and because she grew up in the South she thinks that real maple syrup doesn't taste quite right. So we do keep a little bit of the commercial stuff in the house. Real maple syrup is a lot better. And, you have the illusion that because you've made it yourself, it tastes particularly good. As told to Seth Kugel

ON THE MARKET
Information on properties was provided by owners or listing companies.

WHAT -- 3-bedroom house on 47 acres
WHERE -- Acton, Me.
HOW MUCH -- $377,000

This post-and-beam house with a gambrel roof is 90 miles from Boston and 15 miles from the Atlantic Ocean in an area where maple sugaring is common. The house, built in 1990, has one bathroom, vaulted ceilings with exposed beams and a wood-burning stove that can supplement the oil furnace. The property is a mix of fields, ponds and woods, including maples. There is an oversize two-car detached garage and a second outbuilding that is 30 by 40 feet and heated. Agent: Diane Gilpatrick, Gil Dionne Realty, (207) 324-5264.

WHAT -- 4-bedroom house on 20 acres
WHERE -- Buchanan, Mich.
HOW MUCH -- $175,000

This property in rural southwestern Michigan is an hour from Kalamazoo and a half hour from Lake Michigan. The house is 1,862 square feet and is in need of work. There are two bathrooms and a 40-by-80-foot pole barn. The property's rolling hills have mature maples, oaks and pines. Maple sugaring is common in the area. Agent: Sheryl Crocker, ReMax Four Flags Realty, (269) 362-3131; www.sherylcrocker.com.

HEADLINE: On Florida's West Coast, A Would-Be Palm Beach

BYLINE: By ROBERT ANDREW POWELL

 BODY:
AS you drive in from the Everglades on the Tamiami Trail, Naples announces itself on billboards. ''Premier master-planned gated'' communities with names like Veronawalk and Grandezza offer ''patio homes, single-family homes, and townhomes'' from the $200,000's in some developments to more than $4 million in others.
 At the city's edge, six-lane roads anticipate future construction. Ornate guardhouses protect undeveloped lots of brown dirt that once produced tomatoes and cucumbers. Now, there are paved roads and rows of flags fluttering on plots where houses will soon stand. ''January, February, March and April are our season,'' said Larry White, a real estate agent who works primarily with second-home buyers. ''When the snowbirds come, we work. Before they leave, they'll buy.''
 Naples, once isolated on the southwest coast of Florida, is booming. Two Ritz-Carlton resorts are along the same street. Property values in some developments have grown by a third in the last year alone. Residents enjoy more golf courses per person than anywhere else in America but Myrtle Beach, S.C. More than 100 art galleries fan out from the once sleepy downtown. A population that swells by a third in season, to approximately 280,000, provides enough economic bedrock to support a philharmonic orchestra. 
 When the population spikes in winter, real estate agents step into high gear. A woman who recently sold her horse farm in Kentucky impulsively bought a condo near the shops and restaurants of Old Naples. After visiting Naples for just three days, Chuck Meyer, a retiree from Little Rock, Ark., bought a $4 million house on an estuary just south of the original Ritz-Carlton Naples. 
 ''Naples is just a little more relaxed than anywhere else in Florida,'' said Mr. Meyer, who, along with his wife, owns a third home in Aspen. ''I bought for tax reasons'' -- Florida residents don't pay state income tax -- ''for the weather, and also because it was a gated community, which meant we don't have to worry about our property when we aren't in town.''
 However robust Naples's growth, the city is not for everybody. Unlike Miami or even Tampa, Naples is sound asleep by 10:30. The population is older, socially conservative and startlingly homogenous. Although the number of single, educated young professionals is rising in Naples, the city remains a place where an attractive woman in her 20's, sunning by the pool at La Playa Beach & Golf Resort, is asked by an attendant, in all seriousness, ''What are you even doing here?''
 For those comfortable with the demographics, the appeal of Naples is straightforward: winter temperatures into the 80's. Palm fronds rattled by gulf winds. The energy and enervation of Miami choked off by 110 miles of swaying saw grass. On the car radio, Frank Sinatra sings about having the world on a string. Closer to the Gulf of Mexico, established subdivisions belie Naples's laid-back ethos with high concrete walls, in some cases ringed with barbed wire. 
 ''I don't think that has much to do with security,'' said Joe Ballarino, president of the Naples Board of Realtors, referring to the prevalence of gated communities in the greater Naples area. ''I think it's just a perception that makes the buyer feel like their property is special.''
 THE southwestern tip of Florida was largely free of human life until the 1880's. That's when a Kentucky newspaper baron named Walter Haldeman discovered Naples, and helped plan it, build the town's pier and erect the settlement's only hotel. At one point, after his friends deserted him, he owned the entire town, which he ran largely as a hobby.
 A visiting advertising executive from Chicago jump-started Naples's evolution in 1938. John Glen Sample, bored with Palm Beach, decided to spend a few days in Naples. In what would become a common pattern among tourists, he fell in love with the place and promptly bought waterfront property.
 Sample also purchased land that he developed into Naples's priciest subdivision, Port Royal. He oversaw the installation of sewer lines and the laying of roads. He commissioned a variety of architects to diversify the look of his houses. 
 That was about all he diversified. Sample's vision of a city of wealthy, sophisticated homeowners didn't leave room for the fishing villages that were starting to spring up around town. In advertisements in Vogue, Town and Country, and other upscale publications, he warned that ''Money Alone Won't Buy a Lot in Port Royal.'' ''If he saw a guy wearing brown shoes with black socks or something like that, he wouldn't sell him the house,'' said Doris Reynolds, his former publicist. 
 Sample set the tone for Naples's future development. Ramshackle waterfront shacks blown down in 1960 by Hurricane Donna were replaced with more luxurious housing. (The insurance money that followed the storm also helped things along.) 
 Only a recession in the 70's democratized development. Builders started selling to anybody.
 While that killed Naples's chances of ever rivaling Palm Beach in luxury or prestige, people not named Pulitzer began to feel comfortable investing there. These days, tourists stroll downtown Naples in packs of four -- two men and two women. The dress code is all polo shirts, khaki shorts and white tennis shoes. Along the main drag, Fifth Avenue South, restaurants alternate with real estate agencies and shops that sell a botanical garden of brightly dyed linen dresses. The strip teems with a remarkably similar-looking crowd. In its own way, Fifth Avenue South is as much a convention of like-minded people as Daytona Beach's Main Street during Bike Week.
 Without the guiding hand of early developers like Sample, Naples might have evolved into a much different place. Eastern Collier County -- of which Naples is the seat -- is country music, barbecues and a red Ford F350 with the license plate CWGIRL. That alternate reality is on display at the Swamp Buggy Races on a track called the Mile o' Mud, eight miles east of Old Naples on Rattlesnake-Hammock Road.
 The track is oval with a diagonal lane slashed through, as if it were a no-smoking sign. Brackish brown water covers every inch of it. The water appears to be a foot deep, though it drops to five to six feet deep in three places. The extremely tall buggies driving through these holes disappear up to their steering wheels and exhaust pipes. Buford Reece Gardner, a buggy racer, lives not far from the track and he keeps his swamp buggy, NutRageous, in his backyard. 
 The housing boom in Naples has been good to Mr. Gardner. For 10 years he installed air-conditioners in the big houses rising in Port Royal and elsewhere. The influx of snowbirds kept him busy through the winter, and helped him prosper. On one job alone, he said, the unit he installed cost $300,000. As grateful as he was for the work, he is bittersweet about the town's evolution.
 ''You get some place and pull off the side of the road and see a stand of cypress trees, the sun shining, the birds flying above, and it's just beautiful,'' he said. ''Then, a few months later, you pull into the same spot and it's being bulldozed for some new development.''
 Growth has put buggy racers like Mr. Gardner on notice. Recently he abandoned the air-conditioning business to pursue what seems, in Naples at least, to be a more sensible and potentially lucrative career. He has just completed classes and is awaiting his license. He's going to be a real estate agent.
 ISOLATED several miles north of Old Naples on a strip of beach that has since been colonized by other resort hotels, the Ritz-Carlton was the catalyst for the Naples renaissance when it opened in 1985. Its 51,000-square-foot spa still attracts tourists seeking European facials and relaxation massages. On sunny days, an outdoor mineral pool is ringed by guests roasting in white terry-cloth robes.
 In the Dining Room, the hotel's high-end restaurant, the menu runs to things like venison broth, foie gras with peanut brittle and tiramisu complicated by a dab of green apple sorbet. Denim is forbidden and jackets are required. But on a recent Friday night most of the men had simply slipped blue blazers over their golf shirts.
 Tales of missed putts and long drives mingled with notes from a jazz combo. One man from Minnesota told a joke about ice fishing. It was an appropriate scene for Naples: expensive, sophisticated and preening at times, but still democratic at heart. If you have money, and if you feel the city's attraction, Naples welcomes you.
 Golf is a dominant part of Naples's appeal. The city's first course was carved out in 1919 at a time when only about 100 people lived in Naples. Now around 100 courses snake through the city. At good public courses like the Naples Beach Club, golfers line up in their carts at 7:30 each morning, as if waiting for the start of the Indy 500. 
 To answer the demand, the newer Ritz, the Ritz-Carlton Golf Resort, Naples, features two 18-hole courses designed by Greg Norman. Golf teachers working the courses, together called Tiburon -- Spanish for shark, Mr. Norman's nickname -- break down their guests' swings using a computer. A round of golf can cost as much as $250, a price that hardly dents the savings of most snowbirds who are purchasing homes in the development. While a condo can sell for as little as $200,000, some single-family homes are more than $8 million.
 And business is good, said Mr. White, the real estate agent. ''Sales are strong in areas that are on the water or on the golf course,'' he said. ''Nine/eleven put a little dent in it, but it's since continued to rise and go. When President Bush landed on that air carrier, the phones started ringing and people started spending. It's really taken off.''

HEADLINE: Database Business Helps Oracle to a Solid Third Quarter

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 

 BODY:
The Oracle Corporation, which is pressing its hostile bid to acquire rival PeopleSoft, reported solid gains in third-quarter profit and revenue on Thursday, driven by strong sales of the company's database products. Oracle executives predicted technology spending would continue to improve throughout the year.
 ''This was a very strong quarter for our database business,'' said Jeffrey O. Henley, who was promoted to chairman last year and is the acting chief financial officer.
 While Oracle's database business grew 16 percent, revenue was flat in the closely watched applications business, where it competes with PeopleSoft and the German software maker SAP. In the database business, which accounts for most of Oracle's sales, price competition remains fierce, particularly with Microsoft, company executives said. 
 Wall Street takes a hard look at Oracle's earnings as an indication of the shape of software industry because it announces its earnings a full month before its competitors.
 For the quarter ended Feb. 29, the company, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said net income rose 11 percent, to $635 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with $571 million, or 11 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased 9 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $2.3 billion. The results were in line with analysts' forecasts.
 Before the announcement of the results, shares of Oracle fell 16 cents, to $12.25. After hours, they rose as high as $12.40, before dipping to $12.18.
 During the quarter, Oracle's new software license sales were up 12 percent, to $847 million, and revenue for software license updates and product support was up 17 percent, to $1.2 billion. The company's operating margin was 37 percent, compared with 35 percent in the period a year earlier. 
 ''They were within a few degrees of everything we were looking for,'' said David M. Hilal, analyst at the Friedman Billings Ramsey Group. ''That's positive for them and positive for the group, given that it's normally a tough quarter.'' 
 Oracle's chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, said the company was experiencing a ''fundamental reshaping'' of its business, as its service and consulting business shrinks while its higher-margin software subscription business grows. 
 ''The most profitable portion of Oracle is also the largest portion of our business,'' Mr. Ellison said. 
 Mr. Henley said the company continued to see an overall improvement in technology spending, albeit a gradual one. ''We're optimistic business will modestly improve over the next year,'' he said. ''Business sentiment seems to be getting more confident.'' 
 He said he expected earnings in the fourth quarter, typically the company's strongest, to be 17 cents to 18 cents a share, on a 6 percent to 10 percent increase in revenue.
 The earnings report was Oracle's first since the Justice Department and seven states filed a lawsuit on Feb. 26 to block the company's $9.4 billion unsolicited takeover of PeopleSoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif.
 In a pretrial hearing in San Francisco on Wednesday, Judge Vaughn Walker of Federal District Court set a trial date of June 7. Mr. Ellison said that Judge Walker told the parties that he expected the trial to last four weeks. 
 Meanwhile, the European Union Commission, which is continuing its review of the deal for its impact on the European software market, may submit to Oracle a statement of objections within the next few days or weeks. 
 The statement, a fairly routine filing in deals of this size, will provide Oracle with a description of any problems the commission sees in the proposed merger.
 Oracle representatives declined to comment on whether the company had received one. The commission has set May 11 as the deadline for issuing a decision.
 In its earnings release, Oracle said it spent $15 million during the third quarter on its proposed acquisition of PeopleSoft, and a total of $43 million since making its initial offer nine months ago.

HEADLINE: Staking Out New Condos in a Giant's Turf

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
In the shadow of the gargantuan AOL Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, a century-old onetime telephone exchange is being renovated and expanded into a boutique condominium with 16 residences.
 In the $27 million transformation, 11 apartments, each with two or three bedrooms and 1,800 to 2,700 square feet, will be carved from the existing five-story structure at 426 West 58th Street, near Ninth Avenue. Rising atop that neo-Renaissance style building, built between 1900 and 1906 for the New York Telephone Company, will be a six-story addition comprising five apartments of 2,600 to 3,700 square feet each.
 Motivating the conversion of the building, to be known as West 58, is its location in a neighborhood whose changes are most dramatically signaled by the Time Warner Center, said Miki Naftali, president of Elad Properties, the developer. Elad has converted or built 11 other condominium projects in Manhattan totaling about 500 apartments. 
 Elad's intent, Mr. Naftali said, is to offer buyers a lower-priced alternative to the 201-apartment condominium at the Time Warner Center a block and a half away, where prices start at $2.6 million. Prices at West 58 are $1.4 million to $5 million, he said, adding that the project is to be completed by early next year.
 Mr. Naftali said that since the sales office opened at West 58 on Feb. 29, 10 apartments have been placed under contract, and prices had been raised three times. ''Our buyers are buying from floor plans because they realize their apartments will appreciate in value if they get in at the beginning of the project and the neighborhood,'' said Iva Spitzer, an executive vice president at the residential brokerage firm Douglas Elliman, the sales agent for West 58.
 Monica Blum, president of the 13-block Lincoln Square Business Improvement District, said West 58, just outside her district, would probably be the first of many new residential projects in the neighborhood.
 But Anthony Borelli, district manager at Community Board 4, said that while the Time Warner Center was impressive ''it is too early to tell what impact it will have on the area.''
 Mr. Naftali of Elad said that since his company had focused in recent years on converting commercial structures to housing, it sought out buildings ''that we see potential in and are not necessarily on the market.'' That was the case for the West 58th Street building.
 Adding to the attractions of the building's location and architecture, Mr. Naftali said, was the fact that the building, which he bought for $7.5 million, had only one occupant, the nonprofit Bureau of Jewish Education, making it easier to convert. He said he negotiated for six months with the educational group, which owned and occupied the building for the last 40 years, and closed the sale last September when the group relocated to new quarters in Midtown.
 Also attractive, Mr. Naftali said, was the ability to convert and expand the building without any special zoning approvals. The structure is built around a central courtyard, providing more windows to let light into the apartments. The structure itself could support the six new floors without extensive structural reinforcement, he said, noting that the extra floors were necessary to make the project ''economically feasible.'' 
 Nancy Ruddy, a principal of Cetra/Ruddy, the architectural and interior design firm handling the conversion, recalled that when she first walked through the existing building, it was ''in remarkably good condition and very solid,'' though it consisted ''of lots of teeny offices.'' 
 Ms. Ruddy said that while the structure's masonry walls, about 24 inches thick, and interior cast iron columns were assets when it came to adding the six stories, a steel platform was being built on the roof as a foundation for the addition.
 Gutting the interior, she added, was not an issue, since the office walls were made of sheetrock and came down easily.
 Ms. Ruddy said the addition would be modern in style to create ''a clear delineation of the old and new.'' The new structure will be clad in clear and frosted glass, metal panels and stainless steel that will reflect the sky, she said, and will look as though it is resting lightly atop the older limestone one.
 It will be capped, she said, with ''a modern interpretation of a cornice that respects the architectural order established by the existing building.''

SECTION: Section E; PT1; Column 4; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 3; THEATER REVIEW

LENGTH: 843 words

HEADLINE: Waiting for Oedipus, Putting on a Show

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY

 BODY:
In the world of Craig Lucas life is a scenic journey that eventually takes you right over a cliff. In darkly whimsical dramas like ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' ''Reckless'' and ''The Dying Gaul,'' Mr. Lucas has led theatergoers through witty, tantalizing obstacle courses before pushing them into the dark at the end of the tunnel.
 So perhaps it should come as no surprise to find that he has now enlisted Sophocles, that granddaddy of dramatic fatalism, as the tour guide for his latest play, ''Small Tragedy,'' which opened last night at Playwrights Horizons. The title of this searching, grandly imbalanced work, directed by Mark Wing-Davey, certainly gives its audience fair warning. So does a lyrical opening monologue that is filled with anticipatory dread. 
 Still, it's understandable if you're temporarily lulled into thinking that you're watching a more humane, less snarky version of the film ''Waiting for Guffman,'' Christopher Guest's satire about an amateur theater troupe. Here once again are a posturing, pretentious director whose favorite sound is his own voice and a group of eager, charmingly insecure actors of assorted eccentricities. They have come together to make sense of Sophocles' ''Oedipus Rex.'' Don't make the mistake of enjoying their company too much.
 In both its form and its story ''Small Tragedy'' explores the disconnect between a warm and cozy surface and the forbidding depths beneath. Specifically it considers the culture of denial and insularity that pervades American life and asks if such a society can accommodate a notion as vast as tragedy. Self-knowledge, predeterminism and willed blindness become the stuff of intense conversation during and between rehearsals of Sophocles' masterwork.
 Mr. Lucas triggers this complicated debate by placing two exotic figures of monumental gravity in the midst of a fretful theater company in a rehearsal hall in Cambridge, Mass. One is Sophocles' Oedipus; the other is the man hired to play him, Hakija (Lee Pace), a charismatic economics student.
 Hakija, it turns out, grew up in Bosnia. Suffering and tragic destiny are subjects he knows all about. Small wonder that everyone falls at least a little in love with him. That includes Nathaniel (Rob Campbell), the director; Jen (Ana Reeder), the production's infinitely vulnerable leading lady; and Christmas (Daniel Eric Gold), who is gay, dyslexic and full of gung-ho enthusiasm. This self-contained hothouse of a group is rounded out by Paola (a wonderfully tart Mary Shultz), Nathaniel's wife; and Fanny (Rosemarie DeWitt), Jen's defensive best friend.
 For its first act ''Small Tragedy'' is an impeccably sustained balance of the abstract and the particular, of the comic and the dramatic, as the characters define themselves and their relationships through the hurly-burly of auditions and rehearsal. Mr. Lucas has a shrewd ear for actorly anxiety and vanity. And the cast members generate a truly spontaneous sense of individual personalities and the erotic and intellectual conflicts that arise among them.
 By the middle of the second act, however, the density of ideas and plot starts to eclipse the characters. (Mr. Lucas has loaded Paola and Nathaniel, for example, with a labored personal history that embraces Hollywood deals, alcoholism, sexual game playing and H.I.V.) And in the rushed aftermath of the performance of ''Oedipus'' -- an ungainly and unintentionally semicomic production that improbably places Hakija on a fast track to stardom -- you're likely to feel cheated because people you have come to know have abruptly turned into dramatic pawns.
 ''Life is nothing if not predictable, if you read the clues and know how to put them together,'' Jen says in a monologue toward the play's end. It's true that Mr. Lucas plants plenty of hints early on for the revelations to come, but he doesn't manage to connect the dots convincingly. Surely he could have come up with a better means of disclosing one central character's harrowing secret than the forced device he uses here.
 Yet though it collapses under the weight of its ambitions, ''Small Tragedy'' is filled with provocative questions that American plays should be asking at a fraught and confusing moment in this country's history. Mr. Lucas appreciates that extreme times demand extreme theater. His habitual brooding fatalism has never seemed more relevant. If only he could convey that sensibility, as he has before, without betraying his characters.

HEADLINE: S.&P. and Dow Fall, Eroding Gains of Year-Old Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
United States stocks declined yesterday, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average down for a fourth consecutive day, after bombs killed more than 190 people in Madrid. 
 The synchronized bombing of rush-hour trains gave further impetus to this week's sell-off. Benchmark indexes have fallen since a report last Friday showed a slower-than-expected increase in employment. 
 The S.&P. 500 shed 17.11 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,106.78, placing it in negative territory for the year. The Dow average fell 168.51 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,128.38. The Nasdaq composite index declined 20.26 points, or 1 percent, to 1,943.89, its fifth consecutive drop. It has declined 9.7 percent from a two-and-a-half year high on Jan. 26. The declines eroded some of the gains in a one-year rally that has pushed the three benchmarks up at least 35 percent since their 2003 lows a year ago today.
 Three stocks fell for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. Some 1.9 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, 30 percent more than the three-month daily average.
 Travel-related stocks slumped after news of the bombing. The Bloomberg United States Travel Index, made up of 36 companies that own hotels, airlines, cruise lines and travel agencies, lost 3.2 percent. That is the biggest drop since June 24.
 Continental Airlines fell 70 cents, to $12.27. Carnival, the world's largest cruise-line operator, lost $1.95, to $42.46. Its closest rival, Royal Caribbean, dropped $2.09, to $42.07. Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, owner of the Sheraton and Westin chains, lost $1.09, to $37.60.
 Halliburton fell $1.73, to $28.24. The federal government is conducting a criminal investigation into work done in Iraq by a Halliburton subcontractor.
 Stocks rose in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a House committee that the economy was showing ''increasing signals of recovery'' that should increase job growth soon. The S.&P. 500 gained as much as 0.2 percent.
 ''We needed something good from Greenspan,'' said Richard I. Sichel, chief investment officer of Philadelphia Trust, which manages $1 billion. ''We are closer to seeing job growth; it is the first positive thing we've heard in a week.''
 The Target Corporation added $2.97, or 7.1 percent, to $44.70, for the biggest gain in the S.&P. 500. The company said it might sell the department stores to concentrate on its faster-growing namesake discount chain.
 United States Treasury notes rose after the attacks in Spain, rebounding from earlier losses. ''People want to move out of riskier assets when something like this happens,'' and move into a haven investment, said Paul Calvetti, head of United States Treasury trading at Barclays Capital in New York.
 By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year note rose 10/32 to 102 17/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.69 percent from 3.73 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: GENERAL DYNAMICS IS BUYING ALVIS OF BRITAIN

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
General Dynamics said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Alvis, the maker of the Challenger II battle tank, for $:309 million ($556 million). General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., is offering 280 pence a share for Alvis, 33 percent more than the closing price on Wednesday. Alvis, based in London, will recommend the offer to shareholders, the chief executive, Nicholas Prest, said. Alvis, 29 percent owned by BAE Systems, also makes all-terrain mine-clearing and scouting vehicles. After the acquisition, General Dynamics, builder of the Abrams battle tank, expects to win combat vehicle orders from the United States, Britain and possibly Sweden. Alvis's shares rose 41 percent, to 296 pence.

 BODY:
Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York sold an undisclosed minority stake yesterday to MDC Partners in Toronto, a Canadian agency company that recently bought 60 percent of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York.
 Financial terms of the deal, which had been expected, were not disclosed. 
 The agreement includes an option for MDC to increase its stake in Freeman to 70 percent in about two years, said Miles Nadal, chairman and chief executive at MDC, adding that Freeman would operate autonomously under its current name.
 Freeman was opened in 1987 by Cliff Freeman, a copywriter and creative executive, under the ownership of Saatchi & Saatchi, which sold the agency to Mr. Freeman and other managers in 1999 for about $4.6 million. The deal is part of aggressive American expansion efforts by MDC, which in addition to its stake in Kirshenbaum Bond bought interests in Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami and Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York.
 ''I've talked with everybody over the years'' about deals, Mr. Freeman said, ''but with this one I felt for some reason at home.'' His agency's clients include DSW shoe stores, Fox Sports, Sports Authority and the Turner Broadcasting System.

HEADLINE: Chinese Take Recklessly to Cars (Just Count the Wrecks)

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 11 

 BODY:
For the aspiring motorists taking the driving exam at a government building not long ago, one true/false question probably seemed a touch unusual: If you come upon an auto accident and find a motorist lying unconscious on the road, should you shake that person violently to wake him up? 
 The next question expanded on the theme: If you come upon an accident and find a motorist lying unconscious on the road, and if that person's internal organs are also lying on the road, should you pick up the organs and put them back inside the person?
 The answers, presumably, are false and false.
 Yet if the questions seemed bizarre, the authors of the test, wittingly or not, were providing fair warning that China has become one of the world's most dangerous places to drive. 
 The country's booming economy has established China as the world's fastest growing car market. In Beijing alone, the number of vehicles jumped by more than 400,000 last year, a nearly 25 percent increase.
 But the flood of new cars and first-time drivers have contributed to a fivefold increase in road deaths in the past two decades.
 The roads are often terrible, the drivers are often worse. Traffic safety laws are roundly ignored and, until this year, were badly outdated.
 ''China's not like the United States, where cars have been a way of life for decades, and pedestrians and drivers have established practices,'' said Zhu Xiaomei, 29, a Beijing television producer. ''In China,'' she said, ''the one rule is: no one stops for anyone else. Pedestrians don't stop for cars, and cars don't stop for pedestrians.''
 The anarchic, wacky quality of driving in China might almost be comical if not for the horrific daily carnage. Last year, more than 104,000 people were killed in traffic accidents, roughly two and a half times more deaths than in the United States, even though China has far fewer vehicles. 
 The wrecks are often grotesque. Last Sunday, a busload of migrant workers careened off a mountain road in central China. Twelve died and 35 others were injured. A week earlier, a head-on collision involving a bus in southwest China left 11 dead and 20 injured. During the recent Chinese New Year holiday, one crash claimed at least 40 lives. 
 The maw of traffic can be intimidating to new drivers, some of whom attach small window signs that signal an inexperienced driver is behind the wheel.
 ''Novice drivers are the worst,'' said Tian Zhisheng, 60, as he walked his bicycle against a current of cars in northern Beijing. '' They'll drive right up onto the sidewalk and run you over.'' He added, ''I should put a sign on the back of my bike, 'I'm Old, Don't Hit Me.'' ' 
 China is furiously building highways and roads, but the transportation infrastructure is still woefully inadequate. Cities like Beijing and Shanghai, better designed for bicycles, are choked with traffic. Beijing alone has 63,000 taxis. One silver lining to the traffic is that the death rate is lower in cities. The cars are moving too slow.
 Li Dan, an official with the Chinese Center for Disease Control, said the majority of fatal accidents occur on more rural roads, often on the periphery of cities, where motorists travel faster. Often, these accidents involve passenger buses ferrying migrant workers or others from the countryside into the city. Last year, official statistics showed that China had 41 recorded accidents in which more than 10 people died.
 ''The most serious problem is between the urban and rural areas,'' Mr. Li said. He added, with a touch of understatement, ''There are a lot of things that need to be improved.''
 Within the past year, the Chinese government has taken steps to address the problem, though no one expects an overnight cure. Mr. Li noted that Prime Minister Wen Jiabao had set up a ministerial-level committee to improve road safety. The government has also approved new, nationwide traffic safety laws, scheduled to take affect in May.
 The Road and Traffic Safety Law, among other things, will provide for road signs to mark schools and hospitals. It also, for the first time, will establish that pedestrians have the right of way. Before, a pedestrian run over in an accident was often found at fault. The law will also set severe penalties for hit-and-run accidents, a major problem.
 Still, changing the prevailing culture will be difficult, and enforcing those changes even more so. By one estimate, there are only 200,000 traffic officers in all of China, a country of 1.3 billion people. 
 Violations abound. Some flatbed trucks are so overloaded that their tenuously strapped goods list precariously to one side. Last year, a Chinese newspaper reported that one man made a healthy wage by photographing violations in order to collect reward money from the police.
 Beside violations, ambulance service is spotty even in major cities, and people are often reluctant to call, since in the past the caller has often been responsible for the bill. (The new traffic law changes this.) 
 Nor has the average Chinese driver taken defensive driving to heart. Motorists routinely try to take left turns into four lanes of oncoming traffic in Beijing. Other motorists usually regard such a driver as a lead blocker and follow tightly behind in a vehicular wedge formation. On the outskirts of Beijing, many drivers, particularly in trucks, run red lights with abandon.
 If there is any good news, it is that the number of fatalities fell by about 5,000 from 2002 to 2003. The bad news, though, is that a possible reason for the drop was last year's SARS outbreak. For about two months, people simply stayed home. The roads were practically empty.

 A taxi driver navigates through bicycles in making a right turn in Beijing, where the number of vehicles jumped by more than 400,000 last year. (Photographs by Doug Kanter/Polaris, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Muffles Sweeping Call To Democracy In Mideast

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, yielding to protests from European and Arab leaders, has set aside its plan to issue a sweeping call for economic, political and cultural reform in the Middle East at a June conference of major industrial nations, American and Arab officials said Thursday.
 Because of Arab objections that such a call would give the appearance that change was being dictated from without, the officials said, the summit conference will instead proclaim its endorsement of reforms under way in the Middle East.
 Administration officials said they would work with European leaders to encourage Arab nations to proclaim their own reform measures before the meeting, which is to take place at Sea Island, Ga., with President Bush as host.
 On Wednesday, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met with Jordan's foreign minister, Marwan Muasher, and discussed Jordan's attempt to persuade the Arab League to call for more open societies and democratic institutions at a meeting this month in Tunisia. 
 ''Reform is important and needed in the Arab world,'' Mr. Muasher said in an interview on Thursday. ''We agree with that completely. But for it to work we need ownership of the process, not a one-for-all blueprint from Washington.''
 A draft of the American call for change was circulated to some European countries and then leaked to Al Hayat, a London-based Arabic newspaper, in February -- all before the administration had shown it to Arab leaders, angering many of them.
 ''Our objective is for this document never to see the light,'' Mr. Muasher said of the draft. He said Secretary Powell had accepted the idea that the Sea Island meeting would not adopt the proposal.
 In recent years King Abdullah II of Jordan has led the way in encouraging independent political activities. The United States was so eager to highlight those reforms that it was considering inviting the king and leaders from Morocco, Bahrain and other countries to the meeting.
 That idea has receded, say various officials involved in planning the meeting. A European diplomat said there was a fear that those leaders would be viewed sneeringly as ''good students'' in the Arab world.
 A senior State Department official said that in his meeting with Mr. Muasher, Mr. Powell understood that ''nothing is going to work if it looks like it is being imposed'' and that aid, investment and trade preferences should be used to ''enhance'' the reforms under way.
 Another administration official said the lengthy draft published by Al Hayat was considered dead. It has been denounced by two close allies of Washington, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia. 
 ''All peoples by their nature reject whoever tries to impose ideas on them,'' Mr. Mubarak said.
 European leaders also criticized the draft, citing as well its failure to discuss the need for a peaceful end to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
 The administration last week dispatched Marc Grossman, the under secretary of state for political affairs, to Europe and the Arab world.
 Mr. Muasher, who was visiting Washington on Thursday, said his comments reflected a ''broad consensus among the Europeans as well.''
 Mr. Powell, testifying before the House International Relations Committee, said the text in Al Hayat had caused much misunderstanding. The document, he said, was never intended to be anything more than a draft for discussion.
 ''I think we are now getting a better understanding with the Arab nations that it has to be something that comes from them,'' Mr. Powell said. ''If you don't want us to help, you don't want us to help.''
 Some administration officials said confusion had arisen because the administration had to draft its proposed declaration to be able to present it to Arab leaders, but by then it appeared to be a definitive pronouncement.
 The summit meeting will bring together the leaders of the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Canada and Russia, and leaders of the European Union.

Arafat Calls for Israeli Pullout
By The New York Times
 JERUSALEM, March 11 -- The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, said Thursday that he would welcome an Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip and parts of the West Bank, provided that it was coordinated with the Palestinians and was part of a broader peace effort.

 Mr. Arafat reiterated the Palestinian demand for a full Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza.

PERSON: Robert D. Orr

HEADLINE: Robert D. Orr, 86, Governor Who Revamped Indiana Schools

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 

 BODY:
Robert D. Orr, who championed an educational overhaul as governor of Indiana in the 1980's and later served as an ambassador to Singapore, died here on Wednesday. He was 86.
 The apparent cause was heart arrhythmia, said Mark Lubbers, Mr. Orr's former press secretary and longtime aide. Mr. Orr was admitted to the hospital for surgery because of an apparent kidney blockage, but his condition worsened, Mr. Lubbers said. In December, Mr. Orr underwent surgery for prostate and bladder cancer. 
 Mr. Orr, a Republican, spent 16 years in the state's top two offices, serving two terms as lieutenant governor beginning in 1973 and then as governor from 1981 to 1989. He was barred from a third term.
 After leaving office in 1989, he was named ambassador to Singapore.
 As governor, Mr. Orr presided over the strengthening of the state's economy after the recession of the early 1980's. He also oversaw the removal of the state license branch system from political control and an aggressive effort to promote the export of Indiana products -- a crusade he maintained long after leaving office.
 Mr. Orr's major achievement was passage of a sweeping educational overhaul package in 1987. The ''A-Plus'' package required student achievement exams, a new school accreditation system based on performance and rewards for schools that showed improvement.
 He also pushed two major tax increases through the General Assembly, one in 1982 to fix budget problems and one in 1987 to pay for the education program.
 Mr. Orr was born on Nov. 17, 1917, in Ann Arbor, Mich. He graduated from Yale in 1940 and attended Harvard Business School before enlisting in the Army in 1942. In World War II, he served in the Pacific Theater and was commissioned a major.
 He went to Evansville at the end of the war and entered the family business, the Orr Iron Company. He was Vanderburgh County Republican chairman and was elected to the State Senate in 1968 before being elected lieutenant governor.
 Mr. Orr is survived by his wife, the former Mary Kay Davis, whom he married in 2001, and three children from a previous marriage, to Joanne Wallace.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Warns Congress Not to Create Trade Barriers

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, waded deeper into the political battle over jobs and trade on Thursday by warning Congress not to create trade barriers.
 ''We can erect walls to foreign trade and even discourage job-displacing innovation,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''Tensions might appear to ease, but only for a short while. Our standard of living would soon begin to stagnate and perhaps even decline as a consequence.'' 
 On a day when President Bush continued to spar over trade and jobs with Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, Mr. Greenspan aligned himself with Mr. Bush. 
 Mr. Greenspan disagreed with Mr. Kerry's proposal to link free-trade agreements with commitments by other countries to enforce tougher protections for workers and the environment.
 ''We are an ethical people, and I think we ought to essentially try to spread that around the world, but not use ethics as a guise for protectionism, which I fear in too many instances is really what it's all about,'' Mr. Greenspan told the House Education and Labor Committee.
 Mr. Kerry has vowed to subject trade treaties to an immediate 120-day review if he is elected president. He has also said he would roll back tax incentives that encourage corporations to move jobs overseas.
 Within hours of Mr. Greenspan's testimony, Mr. Kerry once again accused Mr. Bush of allowing manufacturing jobs to leave the country. Since January 2001, the economy has lost 2.2 million jobs. Job creation picked up again last August, but it remained at a near standstill in January and February.
 ''For every month that they've been in office, manufacturing jobs by the tens and hundreds of thousands and millions have been leaving the country,'' Mr. Kerry said Thursday after a meeting with Congressional Democrats.
 Mr. Greenspan pleaded with lawmakers for patience, predicting that job growth would accelerate ''reasonably quickly'' without protectionist measures.
 Invoking icons of free trade like the economist Joseph A. Schumpeter, who described capitalism as a process of ''creative destruction,'' Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that global competition was ''disruptive'' but said the United States had repeatedly prospered by being open and flexible.
 ''Time and again through our history, we have discovered that attempting merely to preserve the comfortable features of the present, rather than reaching for new levels of prosperity, is a sure path to stagnation,'' Mr. Greenspan said.
 Democrats quickly fired back. Mickey Kantor, a former secretary of commerce and top trade negotiator under President Bill Clinton, and now an adviser to Mr. Kerry, said Mr. Greenspan was too optimistic about the job market.
 Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Mr. Greenspan was ignoring the need to fight unfair trade practices by China and other countries.
 ''Alan Greenspan should be focusing on all of the trade barriers that keep American companies from being able to compete,'' Senator Schumer said.

HEADLINE: Bush Campaigns on Long Island, Where Democrats Are Ascendant

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT and PATRICK HEALY

DATELINE: EAST MEADOW, N.Y., March 11 

 BODY:
With suburbia looming as a major political battlefield, President Bush came on Thursday to where it all began: Long Island, where the first modern suburb, Levittown, was born.
 For decades Republicans reigned here, exerting nationwide influence. As recently as the administration of Mr. Bush's father, the party's national chairman was a Long Islander, Richard Bond. 
 But now the suburbs have become a swing vote, and in the New York region lately they have been swinging more Democratic. For the first time, both county executives on Long Island are Democrats. So is the executive in Westchester County, a northern suburb.
 For both parties, wealthy Long Islanders are a mother lode mined by campaign treasurers.
 In his final stop Thursday night, President Bush collected more than $1 million for his campaign, charging $2,000 a head at a fund-raiser at the Carltun restaurant here. Those attending included Wall Street executives living on the North Shore.
 Democrats are sure to follow suit, especially in the Hamptons, the summer playground of liberal-leaning celebrities and business titans.
 The president's trip caused a big stir. ''This is the largest and most exciting thing that's ever happened to this town of Bay Shore,'' said Vincent Trapani, the owner of U.S.A. Industries in Bay Shore, as he welcomed Mr. Bush to a stage set amid factory assembly lines. ''We're ecstatic that you're here.''
 Mr. Bush talked about his economic policies and shared the microphone with selected executives and workers who told their success stories.
 But whether his tour changed any voters' minds is uncertain. Several Hispanic workers at the Bay Shore plant said that they were impressed to see Mr. Bush. But many were not fluent in English and did not understand all he said, and many are not citizens and thus cannot vote. 
 In an unscientific sampling at Mr. Bush's stops, people who said they voted for him before said they would do so again. Supporters of Al Gore four years ago said they intended to vote Democratic again.
 Chants of ''No more Bush'' vied with ''Four more years'' as demonstrators on both sides gathered at key points along the route.
 ''President Bush is one of the best presidents we've ever had,'' said Alfredo Montanez, holding aloft an American flag in Bay Shore, where he runs an appliance store. ''I hope we have him another four years. If it were up to me, I would give him eight.''
 But in the same crowd signs said: ''No blood for oil,'' ''Where Are the Jobs?'' ''Like father, like son, one term and you're done'' and ''Stop the 9/11 Cover-up.''
 Linda Beinhauer, a retiree from Central Islip, said she is a Republican, ''but he won't be getting my vote this year.'' She called Mr. Bush's opposition to gay marriage ''a smokescreen to divert attention from the issue of our jobs.''
 One wavering voter, Cheryl Shames, wore a shirt emblazoned with the image of her brother, Andrew Zucker, who died in the World Trade Center. Mr. Bush's appearance at the groundbreaking for a Sept. 11 memorial here was appropriately apolitical, she said, but ''his having 9/11 in his ads wasn't a positive thing.'' She added: ''I lost my brother that day. I don't think it should be part of his campaign. He's building on other people's grief.''
 Ms. Shames said she voted Democratic in 2000 but grew more at ease with Mr. Bush as president after Sept. 11. Now, she said, she's not sure whom to support.
 Although New York State is still considered a lock for the Democrats, William Kornblum, a sociologist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, said Mr. Bush's appearance here was nonetheless politically shrewd. ''It's the same thing Kerry has to gain by going to Texas,'' Mr. Kornblum said, forcing the opposition to defend its home base.
 The Republican edge in voter enrollment is shrinking on Long Island. In the last 10 years, the Democratic Party has gained twice as many new members in Suffolk County as Republicans have. In Nassau, the ratio was more than three to one.
 The tension between traditional Republican power in the suburbs and the rising Democratic popularity will define the 2004 presidential race, said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York's Graduate Center.
 ''Older suburbs are the battlegrounds for the next election,'' Mr. Mollenkopf said. ''Places like Nassau or Suffolk are going to define who wins the next election. That's where the votes are, and that's where the middle is.''


CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about President Bush's visit to Long Island misstated the precedent for simultaneous Democratic control of the top executive posts in Nassau and Suffolk counties. This is the second time in history, not the first. (In the 1960's, the Nassau County executive was Eugene Nickerson, a Democrat, and the Suffolk executive was H. Lee Dennison, a Republican elected on the Democratic ticket who later became a Democrat.)

HEADLINE: Bush Campaign Goes on Attack in New Anti-Kerry Ads

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG and DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
President Bush's re-election campaign will broadcast its first hard-hitting commercials against Senator John Kerry on Friday, attacking him as ''wrong on taxes, wrong on defense'' and accusing him of not sufficiently ''defending America.''
 The advertisements -- two for television and one on radio -- are the latest example of the White House's willingness to take on Mr. Kerry directly, abandoning the campaign strategy of his father and other presidents who tried to stay above the political fray.
 The Bush campaign presented the new advertisements on a day in which Mr. Bush joined former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York for the groundbreaking of a Long Island memorial to victims of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Democrats criticized the president last week for using images related to the attacks in an earlier round of campaign advertisements. 
 At a Long Island fund-raiser later in the day, Mr. Bush accused Mr. Kerry of running a campaign of anger and said that his opponent ''hasn't offered much about strategies to win the war'' on terrorism.
 Mr. Bush told the audience at the $2,000-a-ticket event in East Meadow that voters would face ''a choice between an America that leads the world with strength and confidence or an America that is uncertain in the face of danger.''
 The attacks on Mr. Kerry are part of an effort to define him on the Bush campaign's terms.
 But strategists and analysts from both parties said on Thursday that the strategy was risky because the confrontational approach might lead the public to view Mr. Bush's presidency in starkly political terms eight months before Election Day.
 ''They've made the decision on a risk-reward basis to do this,'' said Don Sipple, a Republican political consultant who was a consultant to Mr. Bush when he was governor of Texas. ''Obviously, it's an attempt to define Kerry in negative terms during this early period. The risk is that voters could view this as either irrelevant, unseemly or unbecoming of the president of the United States.''
 To help create such a view, Mr. Kerry went before cable news cameras even before the commercials were publicly released and said, ''There is a Republican attack squad that specializes in trying to destroy people and be negative.'' His campaign said it would respond with its own advertising as early as Friday.
 Complicating matters, however, Mr. Sipple said, are new federal election requirements that candidates appear in their own spots to voice approval for them, tying them more closely to their attack ads than ever before.
 Matthew Dowd, Mr. Bush's chief strategist, took issue with the notion that it was risky to begin a confrontational phase of the campaign now. He said that presidents who waited, among them Mr. Bush's father, had paid a price, while those who attacked early, like Bill Clinton, went on to win.
 ''This idea of a Rose Garden strategy is sort of false,'' Mr. Dowd said. ''Voters know he's running for re-election; they know Democrats have been attacking him.''
 In one of the new television commercials, Mr. Bush, without mentioning Mr. Kerry by name, tells voters that they face a choice between going ''forward with confidence, resolve and hope'' and turning ''back to the dangerous illusion that terrorists are not plotting and outlaw regimes are no threat.''
 In a second advertisement, an announcer warns that Mr. Kerry would ''weaken the Patriot Act used to arrest terrorists and to protect America'' and wanted to ''delay defending America until the United Nations approved,'' a reference to his calls for Mr. Bush to build a broader coalition among United Nations members on the eve of the Iraq war. 
 The spots will be complemented by a radio advertisement in which an announcer says, ''His plan to pay for new government spending will raise taxes at least $900 billion including taxes on small businesses -- costing jobs and reversing our economic recovery.'' 
 The spots were to run in the 18 states where Mr. Bush began advertising last week with three spots, two of them making reference to the Sept. 11 attacks. One of the commercials will remain on the air during the next week.
 Some Democrats called the new commercials an indication that the president was so far behind in polls that he felt the need to emerge from the dignity of the Oval Office to fight Mr. Kerry head on.
 ''They're squandering much of the advantage of incumbency and redefining Bush in an entirely political and partisan manner,'' said Jim Jordan, a spokesman for the Media Fund, a Democratic group running advertisements against Mr. Bush. ''This is an open confession that they know they'll lose any race that is remotely a referendum on the Bush presidency.''
 Mr. Bush's aides said he simply had to respond to months of attacks from Mr. Kerry, who was caught off-camera on Wednesday calling his opponents ''crooked'' and ''lying.'' 
 ''It's very important after seven months of attacks that we begin to frame the issues of the campaign,'' said a Bush campaign spokesman, Terry Holt. ''The president is well known; John Kerry is not. For the American people to make a good decision about this election we have to answer the question, Who is John Kerry?''
 The Republicans' efforts to contrast Mr. Bush's leadership skills with those of Mr. Kerry were also on display during the president's trip to Long Island.
 At the fund-raising event, which raised $1.6 million for the re-election campaign, Mr. Giuliani said that on Sept. 11 he repeatedly said to himself ''thank God'' President Bush was in office. Mr. Giuliani and Governor Pataki said they feared what might happen if Mr. Kerry held the post in a similar time of crisis.
 But outside, there was hardly that unanimity of view. Pat Kiefer came with a poster-sized photograph of her son Michael, a firefighter with Ladder Company 132 in Brooklyn who was killed at the World Trade Center.
 ''I have no faith in anyone,'' Ms. Kiefer told reporters on the edge of the crowd. ''The most important thing in my life was taken from me, and they could have prevented it.'' 
 Mr. Bush's advisers have said they are pleased so long as the campaign conversation remains focused on the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath, events they consider to be the defining moments of his presidency. That, they said, is why they are continuing to run the commercial evoking the day.

HEADLINE: Keeping Needed Cash Flowing to Relatives in Haiti

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In the best of times, Boby Express, on a street corner in Flatbush, is a busy place, allowing Haitians in this Brooklyn neighborhood to send money to relatives back in Haiti for whom getting by is an everyday struggle.
 But the past four weeks have been far from the best of times.
 ''Everybody is desperate to send money,'' said Marie Chery, who manages the threadbare money transfer office on Flatbush Avenue near Clarendon Road. 
 With food deliveries in Haiti disrupted by the recent violence and prices multiplying three and four times for whatever foods are available, Haitians like Relax Desane are coming in more often to branches of Boby Express, CAM (Caribbean Air Mail) and dozens of other money transfer outlets to speed more cash to their beleaguered relatives in the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. 
 ''The trouble is that families suffer if we don't send money,'' said Mr. Desane, a 42-year-old barber who works a few doors down on Flatbush Avenue. ''People can't move around. They're scared. People are killing people.''
 He slipped $50 to a clerk behind the bulletproof-glass counter at Boby Express and gave the address of his mother, Marguerite Desut. When he was 12 in 1974, his mother urged him to go to the United States for a better life, and every couple of weeks he has been sending her, his brother, sister and cousins as much as $200 -- a big share of his earnings. 
 The uprising against the government of Jean-Bertrand Aristide is no distant thunder for the New York region's 205,000 Haitian-Americans, 74,000 of them in Brooklyn. Every eruption -- the conquest by rebels of the northern city of Gonaives, the siege of Port-au-Prince, the departure of Mr. Aristide, the appointment of a new prime minister -- has been broadcast to local Haitians by Radio Soleil d'Haiti, the city's Haitian newspapers and Haitian news Web sites like sakapfet.com, and has been felt as a personal jolt. 
 Arguing politics is like a daily workout for immigrants from a country that has suffered 32 coups in the 200 years since it became independent, and recent events are being debated particularly boisterously, usually in Creole, in every barber shop and restaurant in Flatbush. At Boss-Joug, a TV repair shop on Flatbush Avenue, Joseph Saillant, the owner, is worried that his relatives -- four brothers and three sisters -- ''could get killed for no reason'' by menacing street gangs known as chimeres that he said were encouraged by Mr. Aristide. But he will argue in rough but amiable fashion with Jean Robert Duchatelier, owner of the Silence restaurant a few doors down, who takes a more sympathetic view of the Aristide regime. 
 ''Duvalier was a saint compared to Aristide,'' Mr. Saillant said provocatively, invoking the name of Francois Duvalier, the dictator known as Papa Doc who ruled from 1957 to 1971. ''Since he's been in power, what's he done for Haiti?''
 ''I cook chicken and rice and beans -- I don't like politics,'' Mr. Duchatelier replied, smiling coyly and shifting a toothpick in his mouth. 
 But Haitians in the New York region are doing more than just debating academic questions -- they are taking urgent, tangible steps. When the Haitian phone system is working, they use cheap phone cards to call relatives to learn how their day was or whether the electric power is back on and to urge them to stay inside to avoid the bloodshed. 
 New Yorkers like Frantzy Theodule, who owns an electrical supply business, are trying to raise money to create a new town in Haiti that will become a model for future development. And almost every Haitian household here -- where the median income is $37,800 -- is sending cash so relatives can buy food, gasoline and medical supplies.
 For several days last week, the Haitian banking system was closed and money dropped off by Haitians here could not get delivered on the other end. Now these money transfers are going through again, often in minutes. 
 Oscar Herasme, executive director of the National Money Transmitters Association, an industry group based in Fort Lee, N.J., said a survey of members indicated that there has been a 10 percent to 15 percent jump in the amounts sent to Haiti since the troubles began a month ago. The 548,000 Haitians living in America sent $810 million back home in 2002, a quarter of the country's gross domestic product, Mr. Herasme said.
 Money handed over here can be picked up at outlets in Haiti, in either American dollars or Haitian gourdes, or delivered as actual food -- powdered milk, cooking oil, tomato paste, black and red beans and sugar -- to relatives' homes. Senders pay a handling fee of 9 percent for American dollars, 3 percent for gourdes and 6 percent for direct-delivered food. Until last month, money could be sent by messenger to a relative's home, but Ms. Chery of Boby Express, who came here 20 years ago and has business degrees from Brooklyn College, said that her company had stopped the service out of fear that messengers would get mugged. 
 Politically, the Haitian population in New York remains deeply divided even after Mr. Aristide's departure. He was beloved by many. But some prominent Haitians say there has been a shift in sentiment as a result of revelations of the lawlessness and corruption under his regime and brutal attacks by the chimeres.
 ''I do believe within the past month that a lot of pro-Aristide individuals have been increasingly changing their minds,'' said Regine Latortue, a professor of comparative literature in the Africana studies department at Brooklyn College and a second cousin of Haiti's new interim prime minister, Gerard Latortue.
 So close do Haitians here feel to the events in their home country that many of those interviewed spoke only on the condition that their full names not be used for fear of imperiling relatives. A 37-year-old clerk at Boby Express's Flatbush Avenue office gave his name only as Carl. He said he sends 40 percent of his salary not just to support relatives, but also to help friends. Haiti, after all, is a place where people share what little they have.
 ''God will send the money back,'' Carl said, smiling.

HEADLINE: An M.R.I. Machine For Every Doctor? Someone Has to Pay

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON

DATELINE: SYRACUSE 

 BODY:
This aging city is an unexpected epicenter for a high-tech medical arms race. But employers and insurers here say that is just what they are paying for, as doctors, their traditional sources of income squeezed, discover a new one: diagnostic imaging. 
 Instead of sending patients to a radiologist or one of four local hospitals, doctors in Syracuse have been particularly aggressive about installing imaging equipment -- particularly M.R.I. machines -- in their own offices.
 Nationally, diagnostic imaging, which also includes CT and PET scans, is approaching a $100-billion-a-year business, according to a recent report by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, using estimates from the consultant Booz Allen Hamilton, up about 40 percent just since 2000. 
 Indeed, while insurers have long paid the greatest attention to the rising costs of drugs and hospital stays, they are becoming increasingly concerned about imaging. ''There's so much entrepreneurship here that is superseding what is truly needed,'' said Dr. Allan Korn, the chief medical officer for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. ''It's becoming a huge problem.'' 
 In the Syracuse area, the number of magnetic resonance imaging machines has grown by a third over the last three years. In the 12 months ended last June alone, use of M.R.I. scans in the area increased 23 percent, according to National Imaging Associates, a company that works with insurers to manage costs. 
 Competing hospitals and radiologists complain that the imaging upstarts -- orthopedic surgeons, cardiologists, neurologists and others -- are performing services that the radiologists say they do better and that the hospitals say they already provide. They also point to a regulatory environment, on the state and federal levels, which restricts their business but, they say, gives the new competitors free rein to expand. 
 No one disagrees that much of the recent growth in diagnostic imaging is a result of medical advances that allow doctors to better discover what is wrong with a patient or to avoid more invasive procedures, like exploratory surgery. And many patients prefer not having to leave their doctor's office to get an M.R.I.
 ''This is nothing more than changing times -- we have to change,'' said Dr. I. Michael Vella, the president of Syracuse Orthopedic Specialists, the largest orthopedic surgery practice here, with 23 doctors in eight offices across Syracuse. 
 In a building at the edge of a shopping mall that the practice renovated last summer into its main office, the doctors have installed two M.R.I. machines and a nuclear camera, equipment made by General Electric that costs millions of dollars. 
 That is part of a proliferation of M.R.I. machines here, whether in the hospital, at free-standing imaging centers or in doctors' offices. The five counties surrounding Syracuse have 27 M.R.I. machines, up from 20 just three years ago, according to Excellus BlueCross BlueShield, the area's major insurer. Four more are said to be in the works. 
 ''There is just too much equipment,'' said Dr. Patrick J. Lynch, a local radiologist who complains that many specialists are investing in the machines as a way to increase their incomes.
 Employers are also concerned. ''Unfortunately, it's the business community that pays for these,'' said John P. Driscoll, who heads a task force on health care set up by the Metropolitan Development Association of Syracuse and Central New York, a group of business leaders here. 
 Scans, of course, are not inexpensive. While prices vary widely, a typical PET might cost $2,000, while an M.R.I. would cost $700 to $900 and a CT, or computed tomography, scan would cost $500 to $700, according to National Imaging Associates. The tests are frequently covered by insurance, however, so patients would often pay much less, depending on their plan. 
 There are signs that more machines may translate into too much imaging. Excellus points to data that suggest use of M.R.I.'s in Syracuse is two-thirds higher than in Rochester, for example, and higher than the national average. 
 ''There tends to be more self-referral in the Syracuse market,'' said John J. Donahue, the chief executive of National Imaging Associates, based in Hackensack, N.J. 
 But the phenomenon is national. Imaging is the fastest-growing component of physician services in the Medicare program, according to research by the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, an independent federal body that helps Congress evaluate care. Average use per Medicare beneficiary for imaging rose at nearly three times the rate of overall use of doctors' services from 1999 to 2002. And the program's spending on imaging is up about 50 percent over the last five years, versus a 30 percent rise in Medicare's overall costs. 
 ''We share the concern about the possibility for overutilization in imaging technology,'' said Dr. Sean Tunis, the chief clinical officer for Medicare. In a departure from previous policy, Medicare has approved positron emission tomography -- or PET -- scans, which take images using radioactive compounds, for only certain uses, like the diagnosis of thyroid cancer. Medicare is conducting a pilot program before deciding whether to cover scans for the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease.
 Policy analysts say that doctors have strong financial incentives to provide diagnostic imaging and other so-called ancillary services, like lab tests. 
 ''A lot of the impetus comes from the financial pressure physicians are feeling,'' said Dr. Hoangmai H. Pham, a senior health researcher at the Center for Studying Health System Change and one author of a study on physician entrepreneurship that appears in the current issue of Health Affairs, an academic journal. ''Physicians' strategies threaten to raise costs for public and private payers through increased use,'' the study warns. 
 Both specialists and primary care doctors are offering more imaging services, according to research by the Medical Group Management Association, an Englewood, Colo., group that represents large medical practices. Doctors' billings for radiology services climbed 75 percent among family practice groups from 1998 to 2002, while doubling for cardiology groups, the association found.
 ''There are a lot of forces creating this trend,'' including the desire to offer patients convenient and efficient care, said Dr. William F. Jessee, the chief executive of the association. Being able to make a diagnosis and develop a plan for treatment while the patient is still in the office also saves physicians' time, he said.
 As the price of even high-end equipment has come down in recent years, doctors, especially those in large groups, are finding it easier to afford an M.R.I. machine. A typical unit might cost $1.4 million, but doctors can often borrow the money or lease the equipment. Some save money by buying smaller machines that can scan a knee, for example, or purchase used equipment. While payments vary widely, doctors often collect $500 to $700 for a typical M.R.I. done on an outpatient basis in this area. 
 In Syracuse, there have been attempts to discourage the purchase of imaging equipment. In July 2000, Excellus put a moratorium on paying new providers for M.R.I. services. ''We did have some impact on capacity,'' said James R. Smith, Excellus's regional president for central New York.
 But what makes the city particularly vulnerable to a proliferation in equipment is New York's regulatory structure. While hospitals and licensed centers must petition for approval to purchase imaging equipment under the state's certificate-of-need laws, physicians who want to operate the same machines in their offices face no such restrictions. 
 And in some cases, physicians may be in a better position to buy the equipment than the hospitals, as many of the institutions struggle to make ends meet. For example, Crouse Hospital here, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, formed a partnership with the area's largest provider of M.R.I. services, Magnetic Diagnostic Resources of Central New York, to offer M.R.I.'s on hospital grounds.
 ''You either fight them or joint- venture with them,'' said David Speltz, the former chief executive of Crouse, who was brought in to turn the hospital around and remains an adviser. In this case, the hospital could not afford the full cost of the equipment by itself.
 But some executives voice concern about the migration of imaging and other money-making services from their hospitals to physicians' offices. Syracuse hospitals have already felt the impact of doctors and others opening up free-standing surgical centers; the four hospitals experienced an 11 percent drop in ambulatory surgeries from 2001 to 2003, according to the Hospital Executive Council, a local planning group. 
 The competition, some executives acknowledge, fuels duplication of services. 
 ''You have to stay in the race; you have to do it,'' said Ben Moore III, executive director of the University Hospital in Syracuse.
 State officials have been studying some of these concerns. But because the activities of doctors are largely outside the state health department's purview, regulators do not even know how many M.R.I. machines there are in New York. 
 ''We recognize that is, was and will continue to be an issue that we need to deal with and the health care system in New York needs to deal with,'' said Wayne Osten, a state health official. As part of a review of the state's Medicaid system ordered by Gov. George E. Pataki, a working group has begun looking at the migration of services from hospitals to outpatient centers and doctor's offices. 
 But radiologists and others are also troubled by the potential conflict that arises when doctors make money from every test they recommend. Radiologists perform scans on referrals from other doctors. 
 While federal regulations, under the so-called Stark Law, generally forbid doctors from sending patients to imaging centers or labs in which they have a financial interest, doctors are allowed to own and operate equipment in their offices.
 ''There is nothing they can do about the office,'' said Jean M. Mitchell, a professor and health economist at Georgetown Public Policy Institute who has studied the possible conflicts. 
 Efforts in Syracuse to address the continuing buildup in the medical arms race focus largely on having hospital executives, doctors, insurers and others communicate among themselves about the region's needs. But Dr. Vella of Syracuse Orthopedic Specialists, for one, is uneasy about a community planning process that would allow access to technology for some providers but not others.
 ''I don't think that you should limit the use of technology, limit competition,'' he said.
 Mr. Driscoll, the business leader, expects significant resistance from other doctors, as well. 
 ''The doctors have the most to lose,'' he said.
