HEADLINE: New Darlings for Some Inflation-Wary Investors

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
An investment that Wall Street was trying to kill off just three years ago is coming on strong.
 Treasury Inflation Protected Securities are being snapped up by individual investors as well as pension funds and others who are concerned that inflation could erode their returns in coming years.
 Though inflation is near historic lows, the fear is that consumer prices may be poised to rise in the months and years ahead if the economy continues to rebound. If goods and services become more expensive, the low fixed returns offered on standard bonds will have even less buying power.
 The securities, issued by the federal government, pay the investor a set interest rate, and their principal gains in value along with the rise in the Consumer Price Index. Since the Treasury began selling this type of security to a lackluster reception seven years ago, the market has swelled. Now, what is widely called the TIPS market has nearly $200 billion in circulation. And in an unusual market twist, the securities seem to be more profitable for investors than for Wall Street, which was lobbying for their demise not so long ago. 
 ''What Wall Street doesn't like about them -- the 'buy and hold' mentality -- is what makes TIPS good for investors,'' said Dan Bernstein, director of Research at Bridgewater Associates, which manages more than $3.5 billion in the inflation-indexed securities.
 While the market for these securities is tiny compared with the regular Treasury market, which totals $3.6 trillion, it is about to grow at a faster clip. Along with the 10-year version, the government is expected to issue one or two new terms in May. A 5-year and a 20-year are considered likely possibilities. With this addition, annual sales could rise, to perhaps $60 billion, from about $30 billion last year. 
 More important, demand among investors is growing quickly. If institutions like pension funds become convinced that the market is large enough to accommodate their needs, the demand could surge.
 The shift from government surplus to budget deficits has also changed the landscape. Wall Street found the inflation-protected securities to be more of a nuisance than a profit-making tool in part because the market was too small. 
 TIPS were ''on their deathbed in the summer of 2001,'' said Tim Bitsberger, deputy assistant Treasury secretary for federal finance. ''We decided we would remain committed to TIPS, but few believed us.''
 ''In the past six months,'' Mr. Bitsberger said, ''many firms have been reallocating resources to TIPS.'' 
 Tom Kalaris, the chief executive at Barclays Capital, Americas, was an early proponent of the inflation-protected securities. ''The product,'' he said, ''has arrived.'' 
 Investors from big to small are jumping on the bandwagon. The pension funds of New York State and New York City, among the largest retirement funds in the country, with almost $200 billion in assets, have decided to allocate 3 percent to 7 percent of their portfolios to the inflation-protected securities. Some other pension funds are doing the same, as are big endowments. Harvard has put 6 percent in its Policy Portfolio, which is a guideline for asset allocation. 
 At the same time, more individual investors are buying the securities. For the eight months through February, $3.9 billion has flowed into mutual funds that buy mostly inflation-protected securities, according to AMG Data Services. That was 30 percent of the total inflow into taxable bond funds. 
 Just as people think of such investments as natural for their retirement funds, pension funds see them as a way to meet their obligations, because many pension payments are tied to inflation.
 Adam M. Blumenthal, the first deputy comptroller for New York City, said the securities provide diversification because they tend to move in the opposite direction from stocks and bonds over time. They are also less volatile than stocks and normal bonds. ''Although the market is still small,'' he said, ''we believe it is large enough to absorb the allocation'' of the city's pension funds. 
 Paul Mussche, the head of government strategy at Deutsche Bank Securities, said ''the move by New York State and New York City is a trend that bodes well for TIPS.''
 Investors need to be cautious, though, because of the recent run-up. The inflation-protected securities had a total return of 7.3 percent for the 12 months ended in February, compared with 2.9 percent for regular Treasuries. After being undervalued for a while, the securities are at best fairly valued now, say many analysts, suggesting investors need a long-term view to make them worthwhile. ''People will be happier 20 years from now having held TIPS rather than regular Treasury bonds,'' said Chip Plumb of Evanston, Ill., a consultant who appraises the value of businesses. His domestic fixed-income portfolio, which is about 20 percent of his total investments, is in the securities.
 But for Wall Street, the securities have not been that popular. Only a handful of Wall Street firms have a significant, full-service commitment to the market. One reason is that investors like to buy and hold the securities, meaning they do not trade a lot, and Wall Street makes money on trading. In addition, the lower volatility crimps Wall Street profits.
 But this may be changing as interest grows worldwide in this type of securities. Though not one of the early participants in the market, the United States is now the biggest issuer. The global market, led by Britain, is also growing. Italy issued its second inflation-linked bond in February, and Japan sold its first issues of inflation-linked bonds last week. Germany is considering it, and France has been a long-time issuer. 
 The market for other types of securities linked to inflation is also swelling. There are now swaps, in which investors trade long-term and short-term interest payments, linked to inflation. There is a futures contract based on the Consumer Price Index now trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Fannie Mae, the government-sponsored mortgage agency, issued an inflation-linked bond last month, its first since 1997. 
 ''We see that the breadth of users are increasing,'' said Sanjay Verma, head of United States government trading at Morgan Stanley. ''It has become a necessary product if we are going to be a full-service bank.''
 To that end, Morgan Stanley hired a TIPS research specialist away from Barclays last year and now has full-time traders devoted to the Treasury securities and inflation derivatives. 
 Michelle Cunningham, director of internal fixed income at the California State Teachers Retirement System, said that right now the TIPS market ''is a bit small for us,'' making it difficult to own enough of the securities to make an impact in a fund its size. The California Public Employees Retirement System, which is the largest in the nation, is not making a fixed allocation to the securities either.
 Still, both funds have bought some of the securities when their analysts thought they were a bargain, and Ms. Cunningham said she was interested in them as a long-term investment. ''For a pension fund with liabilities affected by inflation, TIPS would be a good hedge,'' she said. For this kind of buying, though, she said the market should be around $500 billion in outstanding securities.
 The critical mass could be achieved, though, given the Treasury's additional commitment and the enormous amount of borrowing the government will have to do over the next several years to cover projected budget deficits.

HEADLINE: U.S. Wins Ruling In Mexico Case

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12 

 BODY:
The United States said on Friday that it had won a victory at the World Trade Organization that could save consumers and companies billions of dollars on phone calls to Mexico. 
 Mexico now requires United States telecommunications carriers to connect with Mexican carriers to complete calls from the United States. 
The government also grants Mexico's dominant carrier, Telefonos de Mexico, known as Telmex, the exclusive authority to negotiate the rate for connecting calls into Mexico.
 The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, said in a statement that the W.T.O. agreed that Mexico's regulations violated international trade rules. Telmex may now be forced to charge lower rates for using its network, or Mexico could risk trade sanctions.
 Both the United States and Mexico have the right to appeal the W.T.O. ruling. If neither country exercises that option, the ruling will be adopted by the W.T.O., with the recommendation that Mexico comply with the decision.

HEADLINE: All This Progress Is Killing Us, Bite by Bite

BYLINE: By GREGG EASTERBROOK. 
Gregg Easterbrook, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution, is the author of ''The Progress Paradox: How Life Gets Better While People Feel Worse'' (Random House).

 BODY:
YOUR great-great grandparents would find it hard to believe the Boeing 747, but perhaps they'd have a harder time believing last week's news that obesity has become the second-leading cause of death in the United States. Too much food a menace instead of too little! A study released by the federal Centers for Disease Control ranked ''poor diet and physical inactivity'' as the cause of 400,000 United States deaths in 2000, trailing only fatalities from tobacco. Obesity, the C.D.C. said, now kills five times as many Americans as ''microbial agents,'' that is, infectious disease.
 Moon landings might seem less shocking to your great-great grandparents than abundance of food causing five times as many deaths as germs; OutKast might seem less bizarre to them than the House passing legislation last week to exempt restaurants from being sued for serving portions that are too large. 
 Your recent ancestors would further be stunned by the notion of plump poverty. A century ago, the poor were as lean as fence posts; worry about where to get the next meal was a constant companion for millions. Today, America's least well-off are so surrounded by double cheeseburgers, chicken buckets, extra-large pizzas and supersized fries that they are more likely to be overweight than the population as a whole. 
 But the expanding waistline is not only a problem of lower-income Americans who dine too often on fast food. Today, the typical American is overweight, according to the C.D.C., which estimates that 64 percent of American citizens are carrying too many pounds for their height. Obesity and sedentary living are rising so fast that their health consequences may soon supplant tobacco as the No. 1 preventable cause of death, the C.D.C. predicts. Rates of heart disease, stroke and many cancers are in decline, while life expectancy is increasing -- but ever-rising readings on the bathroom scale may be canceling out what would otherwise be dramatic gains in public health.
 O.K., it's hard to be opposed to food. But the epidemic of obesity epitomizes the unsettled character of progress in affluent Western society. Our lives are characterized by too much of a good thing -- too much to eat, to buy, to watch and to do, excess at every turn. Sometimes achievement itself engenders the excess: today's agriculture creates so much food at such low cost that who can resist that extra helping? 
 Consider other examples in which society's success seems to be backfiring on our health or well-being.

PRODUCTIVITY. Higher productivity is essential to rising living standards and to the declining prices of goods and services. But higher productivity may lead to fewer jobs.
 Early in the postwar era, analysts fretted that automation would take over manufacturing, throwing everyone out of work. That fear went unrealized for a generation, in part because robots and computers weren't good at much. Today, near-automated manufacturing is becoming a reality. Newly built factories often require only a fraction of the work force of the plants they replace. Office technology, meanwhile, now allows a few to do what once required a whole hive of worker bees. 
 There may come a point when the gains from higher productivity pale before the job losses. But even if that point does not come, rapid technological change is instilling anxiety about future employment: anxiety that makes it hard to appreciate and enjoy what productivity creates.

TRAFFIC. Cars are much better than they were a few decades ago -- more comfortable, powerful and reliable. They are equipped with safety features like air bags and stuffed with CD players, satellite radios and talking navigation gizmos. Adjusted for consumers' rising buying power, the typical powerful new car costs less than one a generation ago.
 But in part because cars are so desirable and affordable, roads are increasingly clogged with traffic. Today in the United States, there are 230 million cars and trucks in operation, and only 193 million licensed drivers -- more vehicles than drivers! Studies by the Federal Highway Administration show that in the 30 largest cities, total time lost to traffic jams has almost quintupled since 1980. 
 Worse, prosperity has made possible the popularity of S.U.V.'s and the misnamed ''light'' pickup trucks, which now account for half of all new-car sales. Exempt from the fuel-economy standards that apply to regular cars, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks sustain American dependence on Persian Gulf oil. A new study in the Journal of Risk and Uncertainty showed that the rise in S.U.V.'s and pickup trucks ''leads to substantially more fatalities'' on the road. 
 So just as longevity might be improving at a faster clip were it not for expanding waistlines, death rates in traffic accidents might show a more positive trend were it not for the S.U.V. explosion. 
 The proliferation of cars also encourages us to drive rather than walk. A century ago, the typical American walked three miles a day; now the average is less than a quarter mile a day. Some research suggests that the sedentary lifestyle, rather than weight itself, is the real threat; a chubby person who is physically active will be O.K. Studies also show that it is not necessary to do aerobics to get the benefits of exercise; a half-hour a day of brisk walking is sufficient. But more cars, driven more miles, mean less walking.

STRESS. It's not just in your mind: Researchers believe stress levels really are rising. People who are overweight or inactive experience more stress than others, and that now applies to the majority. Insufficient sleep increases stress, and Americans now sleep on average only seven hours a night, versus eight hours for our parents' generation and 10 hours for our great-grandparents'.
 Research by Bruce McEwen, a neuroendocrinologist at Rockefeller University in New York, suggests that modern stress, in addition to making life unpleasant, can impair immune function -- again, canceling out health gains that might otherwise occur.
 Prosperity brings many other mixed blessings. Living standards keep rising, but so does incidence of clinical depression. Cellphones are convenient, but make it impossible to escape from office calls. E-mail is cheap and fast, if you don't mind deleting hundreds of spam messages. The Internet and cable television improve communication, but deluge us with the junkiest aspects of culture.
 Americans live in ever-nicer, ever-larger houses, but new homes and the businesses that serve them have to go somewhere. Sprawl continues at a maddening pace, while once-rustic areas may now be gridlocked with S.U.V.'s and power boats. 
 Agricultural yields continue rising, yet that means fewer family farms are needed. Biotechnology may allow us to live longer, but may leave us dependent on costly synthetic drugs. There are many similar examples.
 Increasingly, Western life is afflicted by the paradoxes of progress. Material circumstances keep improving, yet our quality of life may be no better as a result -- especially in those cases, like food, where enough becomes too much. 
 ''The maximum is not the optimum,'' the ecologist Garrett Hardin, who died last year, liked to say. Americans are choosing the maximum, and it does not necessarily make us healthier or happier.

HEADLINE: Officials Seek Approval to Begin Wider Testing for Bird Flu

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
Government and poultry industry officials intend to expand testing for bird flu to cover most of the poultry raised in the United States, possibly this month, an Agriculture Department official said Friday.
 The $12.5 million program would focus on the most dangerous forms of the most common variety, low pathogenic avian influenza. These forms, known as H5 and H7, can be no worse than the chicken equivalent of the common cold. If left to spread, however, they can mutate into highly pathogenic varieties that can kill entire flocks in a day. 
 The new testing system could take effect March 29 if it gets final Bush administration approval, said Andrew Rhorer, senior coordinator of the Agriculture Department's poultry improvement plan. The plan was approved on March 5 by a committee of federal, state and industry officials that oversees the program, he said.
 Until now, low-path bird flu had gotten a low priority from regulators. The disease is found in nations worldwide, and governments are not required to notify international livestock health officials when an outbreak occurs. High-path flu, on the other hand, does require notification, which triggers poultry export embargoes.
 But even the low-path form can be economically devastating. Sick chickens do not grow as fast as healthy ones, so growers have to keep the birds longer and spend more on feed. States sometimes order flocks killed and have quarantined infected farms to prevent the virus from spreading. In addition, importing nations sometimes ban exports from low-path infected areas.
 Current testing for low-path bird flu focuses on birds raised for breeding that will be exported to nations which require certification that the animals are free of low-path bird flu, said T. J. Meyers, co-director of the Agriculture Department's National Center for Animal Health Programs.
 State health officials test other flocks if they hear of birds that show symptoms. There is no federal testing program for low-path bird flu.
 But the current system leaves out commercial flocks raised for meat or eggs, which are almost all of the nation's estimated 9 billion chickens. The new plan would change that, as well as allow tests in turkeys.
 Recent outbreaks of low-path bird flu in Delaware, Maryland and Pennsylvania led to a spate of bans which, after a separate high-path bird flu infected a flock in Texas, reached about 35 nations.
 The blood tests could be done on the farm or at the slaughterhouse, said Dr. John Smith, health and hatchery director of Fieldale Farms, a poultry company in Baldwin, Ga. As chairman of a poultry committee of the United States Animal Health Association, a livestock industry professional organization, Dr. Smith, a veterinarian, worked with the poultry improvement plan committee to draft the testing proposal.

HEADLINE: Emulating the Real and Vital Guthrie, Not St. Woody

BYLINE: By WILLIAM HOGELAND. 
William Hogeland has written about music for The Atlantic Monthly and Slate.

 BODY:
WOODY GUTHRIE'S ghost must be getting exhausted. Ever since Guthrie -- the Oklahoma-born singer, writer and activist who wrote and recorded American classics like ''This Land Is Your Land'' -- died in 1967, musicians on the political left have been invoking his spirit. 
 Lately the invocation has grown insistent, as the singer-songwriters Steve Earle, Billy Bragg and Tom Morello -- and others featured in Tell Us the Truth, a recent concert tour protesting policies of the Bush administration -- have seemed to be trying to unearth Guthrie in an almost literal way. The Tell Us the Truth artists copy, conjure and channel Guthrie, and what emerges from all their reverence is a painted St. Woody, soapbox artist of the oppressed, emptied of the qualities that made Guthrie the messy, iconoclastic musical charmer he really was. In the process, normally incisive musicians like Mr. Bragg and Mr. Earle, not surprisingly, become boring. 
 But there's good news: the real Woody Guthrie -- a small and wired man who embraced irreverent satire, stark lyricism, spiritual aspiration and unpredictable silliness -- is getting a hearing, too. The Bottle Rockets, bar-style rockers with comedic smarts and a small, devoted following, don't express abject reverence toward Guthrie or make bald claims on his legacy. Yet his wilder presence is alive and kicking in their music. Treating guitar-drenched bar rock as a kind of American tradition, the Bottle Rockets' songwriting makes them the keepers of his idiosyncratic legacy. Boring they are not.
 The Bottle Rockets' new album, ''Blue Sky,'' expands on subject matter they have made their own in a handful of irresistible CD's. The Bottle Rockets recount ordinary problems -- sometimes romantic misadventures and inner turmoil but also, more characteristically, day-to-day hassles and joys -- with a self-deprecating, good-hearted wit.
 ''Blue Sky'' opens with the punningly titled ''Lucky Break,'' a rousing folk-rock anthem to being injured on the job and thus free to lie around collecting checks. In the intro, a lonely yet resilient harmonica skirls around the acoustic guitar -- a sound that Guthrie pioneered and generations of folkies have made an all-purpose signifier of sincerity. The chorus -- ''I fell down/ So here I lay,/ Got the Workman's Comp/ So everything's O.K'' -- is hilarious because it's truly stirring. A triumphant bridge dismisses the dignity of labor and worker solidarity with an offhandedness seemingly calculated to offend idealists.
 So is this Guthrie parody or Guthrie homage? Both, it appears. The song may mock Guthrie the naively earnest bard of labor, but it draws energy from Guthrie the freely confrontational American poet. The verses' deft rhymes, conversational tone and eye for specifics -- Bottle Rockets trademarks -- recall Guthrie satires like ''So Long, It's Been Good to Know Yuh,'' which makes social comedy out of a destructive dust storm. That song skewers authority, in the form of an end-is-near preacher who nevertheless makes sure to pass the plate, and rhymes ''text,'' ''specs'' and ''collection'' as if there were nothing to it.
 Like ''So Long,'' ''Lucky Break'' gets laughs from bleak realism and rhyming wit. The Bottle Rockets have actually written a new kind of labor protest song, a dark and ambiguous one that also insists on being infectious and fun, that evokes ordinary people's struggles without resorting to arid agitprop, just like Guthrie at his best.
 Guthrie's sprawling catalog includes ''Hard Travelin','' about a migrant's endless search for work, which bubbles along with such pleasure in language and rhythm that it underplays (and thus makes real) the rigors it describes. His ''Do Re Me'' treats with joyous sarcasm the disappointments faced by Dust Bowl refugees in California.
 The Bottle Rockets pick up on these qualities in songs like ''Man of Constant Anxiety'' (also on ''Blue Sky''), which laughs at the ''O Brother'' cult of hillbilly authenticity while listing the mounting pressures on a real working person. (The song's almost one-note guitar solo is a brilliantly funny evocation of inner agitation.) ''Gotta Get Up,'' from the Bottle Rockets' earlier ''Brand New Year,'' is a driving rock nightmare that doesn't so much describe as embody the breathless, rat-on-a-wheel cycle of work week and weekend.
 As in Guthrie's best writing, these and the band's other songs lessen the power of economic hardships not by indulging in slogans, or even soliciting a listener's sympathy, but simply by naming those troubles, even reveling in them, with a kind of ferocious delight.
 The Bottle Rockets' ''Welfare Music'' (from the album ''The Brooklyn Side'') devotes an entire verse to a baby dancing on the floor, falling down, getting up. That verse recalls another aspect of Guthrie's work: ingeniously action-inspiring tunes like ''Put Your Finger in the Air'' and ''Riding in My Car.''
 Guthrie's many children's songs, which seem almost too basic to have authorship, distill the pleasure in movement that marks the most vital parts of his catalog. They are a window into his purest creative method, which sprang from impulses far more primal than any desire to browbeat.
 It's true that as part of the 1930's and 40's ''people's songs'' movement, Guthrie wrote dumb ditties under the aegis of the American Communist Party, supporting Stalinism and opposing American entry into World War II. In the same driven, lock-step party mood, he put the slogan ''This Machine Kills Fascists'' on his guitar, a move admired and even copied by Tell Us the Truth artists, who sometimes seem nostalgic not for a poet but for a party hack. The Bottle Rockets tap into the vein of play, expressed most fundamentally in Guthrie's children's songs, which inspires a far more generous range of moods than overdetermined sloganeering can.
 That kind of play takes a rowdy, grown-up form in rock 'n' roll, which can, of course, embrace the political, the romantic, the sexual, even the depressed. In the Bottle Rockets' music, Woody Guthrie lives on in ways that don't reduce his humanity and originality to cliches, despite his own all-too-human tendency, at times, to reduce himself.

HEADLINE: Wholesalers Eye Queens As a Warehouse Wonderland

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY

 BODY:
Jay Chung, a wholesaler of desk clocks and snow globes on West 27th Street near the Avenue of the Americas, believes that he and his business partner have found his industry's promised land in northern Queens. It is 26 acres of soggy soil that was once Flushing Airport and is now part of the College Point Corporate Park, a low-lying area convenient to several expressways and La Guardia Airport. 
 Mr. Chung and 52 other wholesalers have proposed to spend $175 million to construct a two-story, 585,000-square-foot warehouse complex that could be a center for 180 wholesale businesses. In one swoop, the project would shift New York's traditional wholesale district, around Broadway between 25th and 35th Streets in Manhattan, to Queens. And as far as Mr. Chung is concerned, the move cannot come soon enough. 
 ''The rent is sky-high and rising and traffic every day here is worse,'' he said from his office in Manhattan. ''A lot of buyers have difficulty parking, and you need to park to buy.'' In addition, six residential high-rises have sprung up in the district in recent years, and many of the residents are not happy about living among the cluster of wholesale businesses. 
 A few weeks ago, the city's Economic Development Corporation chose the warehouse proposal from among 12 plans to develop the site, in part because the agency believes that the center would bring 600 existing jobs to the area and create 420 new jobs over five to seven years. 
 But some local civic groups and elected officials are unhappy about not having had a chance to evaluate the various proposals. ''We never saw them,'' said Adrian Joyce, a member of Community Board 7. ''The mayor spoke out prematurely when he said he was going to do this.'' 
 Mr. Joyce said he was concerned that local roads would be overwhelmed by truck traffic and that savvy shoppers might go to the warehouse to buy items at wholesale prices, bringing even more traffic. ''Who's going to police them to stop them from selling retail?'' he asked. 
 In response, Mr. Chung said that his company, College Point Wholesale Distribution Development, would turn away ordinary shoppers and allow in only buyers with federal tax ID's for retail businesses. 
 Janel Patterson, an Economic Development Corporation spokeswoman, said the project would provide other benefits, like the $2 million Mr. Chung's company has committed to build a nature trail around the site's perimeter. The city has also set aside $8 million to improve local traffic flow by repairing and perhaps extending nearby Linden Place, which is closed because of chronic flooding. 
 But Mr. Joyce and his allies remain opposed. They plan more meetings and -- although Ms. Patterson said her agency does not customarily divulge unchosen proposals -- they hope to learn about them so they can be presented in the court of public opinion. 
 ''This is not a dead issue,'' Mr. Joyce said. JIM O'GRADY

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1; How to Make a Wealthy City Less Poor

LENGTH: 2614 words

HEADLINE: Governor Gambles on a Developer Who's a Preservationist

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: CAPE MAY 

 BODY:
GOVERNOR McGREEVEY sat in the dining room of the Congress Hall hotel one early fall morning two years ago, enjoying a rare moment of calm -- no urgent messages from his staff, no ringing phones. So he could well have felt a twinge of annoyance when a slim, well-dressed man approached, quietly introduced himself as the owner of the hotel, and asked if there was anything he could do to improve his guest's stay.
 What's good for breakfast? the governor asked, gesturing for the man to sit. Oatmeal with blueberries, replied the man -- special of the house. 
 With this inquiry the mayor's breakfast partner, the developer Curtis Bashaw, was displaying his trademark hotelier's attentiveness. But the conversation, continuing off and on over meetings at the hotel for the next few days, showcased other talents of Mr. Bashaw's, as well as his ideas about the future of the Jersey Shore and how Atlantic City's casino gambling fits into that picture. 
 By the time the governor was ready to return to Trenton, he said in a recent interview, he thought Mr. Bashaw was someone worth remembering. And this February he named Mr. Bashaw to head the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, an obscure but powerful agency that funnels tens of millions of dollars to development projects along the shore each year. The authority, known by its acronym, Creda, has slowly changed the region since its creation 20 years ago, paying for roads, hotel rooms, apartment buildings and shopping districts. 
 Gambling had long been weighing on the governor's mind. A bruising fight over the amount that casinos pay in taxes occasioned a stock-taking, and what it revealed wasn't pretty: after years of growth, gambling revenues were flat, and Atlantic City faced increasing threats from new casinos in New York, as well as video lottery terminals planned for neighboring states. 
 The more Mr. McGreevey studied the situation, the more he felt that the bet on gambling had been too heavy; outside of the casinos, there was little to attract people to Atlantic City, despite its 40,000-strong population. For one thing, he learned that while Atlantic City and Las Vegas have almost identical gambling revenue -- about $4 billion -- Las Vegas doubles that amount through restaurants, hotels and retail. In Atlantic City, those revenues are negligible. 
 ''We have lacked a coherent vision in Atlantic City,'' the governor said in the interview. 
 He clearly views Mr. Bashaw -- with his hotelier's background -- as the antidote to that problem. Yet in many ways Mr. Bashaw is an unusual choice. He has no government background and little experience in dealing with casinos, which have dominated the region's development for over 20 years. 
 As for the industry itself, it seems to welcome new blood.
 ''New ideas and development experience is what the job requires,'' said Bob Boughner, chief executive of the Borgata, the newest and largest hotel and casino in the city.
 Judging from Mr. Bashaw's resume, he would appear to have both. He developed his first hotel before he turned 30, and his projects in Cape May have become linchpins of its resurgence. Plus, the governor said, the man knows his hotels. ''The oatmeal was delicious,'' he said.

'South Bronx by the Seashore'
 When voters approved gambling for Atlantic City in 1976, one of its primary goals was the renewal of a metropolis racked by crime, poverty and decay. ''It was a bleak urban situation,'' said James W. Hughes, dean of Rutgers University's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, and author of a book on the city. ''Before the first casino opened in 1978, the best characterization of Atlantic City at the time was the South Bronx by the seashore.''
 Gambling, Dr. Hughes said, promised an immediate influx of cash. And in one way the promise has been fulfilled.
 The city has ''one of the strongest economic bases of any city in New Jersey,'' he said. ''The casino industry is a very powerful industry; it represents about 40,000 jobs.''
 But at the same time, many feel that the influx has not done enough to improve the lives of Atlantic City residents.
 ''The promise of gambling was that it would be a unique tool of urban development,'' said Bryant Simon, a University of Georgia history professor who is writing a book on gambling and Atlantic City. ''By that measure it has failed.''
 Professor Simon is not the only one to point out that the city has lost population, services and businesses since the casinos opened.
 ''When gambling came, there were still five movie theaters in town; there were still supermarkets; there were still a fair number of stores on Atlantic Avenue,'' he said. ''All that stuff is gone now.''
 He does not hold the casinos financially responsible for those changes. In fact, through special taxes, the industry has contributed billions to both city and state over the past 20 years. Rather, he said, it is the very nature of gambling in Atlantic City that has created pockets of wealth surrounded by poverty. 
 ''They wanted the casinos to be self-contained -- that is why the oceanfront hotels have no ocean views,'' Professor Simon said. ''The effect was to create 12 separate islands.''
 The effect was also to base the city's economy almost entirely on gambling. Unlike Las Vegas, which derives nearly half its revenue from tourists who patronize restaurants and other attractions, Atlantic City has little to offer apart from the gambling floors.
 That is something everyone concerned wants to change.
 ''We all have a common goal in making sure that Atlantic City is a place to go for more than playing the slot machines,'' said State Senator William Gormley, a Republican who represents the city.
 Although the senator agrees with Professor Simon's main point, he disputes much of his analysis. He asserted that the city had made great efforts to develop a non-gambling economy, with the construction of the Atlantic City Convention Center and a 400,000-square-foot shopping area that recently opened downtown. 
 He also said the casino industry was investing in other attractions. 
 For instance the Borgata, which opened last year, has restaurants and shopping as well as gambling. ''Diversification is essential for the future,'' said Mr. Boughner, the Borgata C.E.O. ''We fashioned the Borgata more along the lines of a Las Vegas hotel, versus being trapped by the constraints of the Atlantic City model.''
 The casino owners have endorsed the idea of expanding their revenue base. The owners of the Tropicana and Caesar's both plan new space for restaurants and shopping, and the casino trade organization is calling for a large increase in the number of hotel rooms.
 ''The difference between Las Vegas and Atlantic City is simple,'' said Mark Sandson, the lawyer for the Casino Association of New Jersey. ''Vegas has 120,000 hotel rooms, and Atlantic City has 14,000. Real growth in Atlantic City is going to be about developing a non-gaming infrastructure.''
 With most of the money for improvements flowing through Creda, Mr. Bashaw's appointment to head it amounts to a clear signal that the governor wants to diversify the city's attractions. In fact he described Mr. Bashaw -- with his background in hotel development and master's degree in finance from Wharton -- as the ideal person to remake the city.
 ''He has the vision and the tenacity to bring about change,'' Mr. McGreevey said. ''Look at the change he has brought to Congress Hall and Cape May.''

The Lessons of Cape May
 Perched on a hill just beyond a curve of Beach Avenue, the imposing edifice of the Congress Hall hotel looms over Cape May's gingerbread Victorians like an oak tree in an ornamental garden. Four stories tall, yellow brick with soaring pillars and a slate mansard roof, the hotel breathes power like a small bit of Washington scooped up and dropped on the Jersey Shore.
 Originally built in 1816, the hotel was the summer White House for presidents from Buchanan to Harrison and was celebrated in John Philip Sousa's ''Congress Hall March.''
 Like the rest of Cape May, the Congress Hall was a celebrated destination of the steamship era. Passengers moving up the coast found the town a convenient stopping point on the way to New York, and wealthy vacationers from Washington and Philadelphia colonized the spot, enjoying the salt air and ocean breezes. Photos from the era show gentlemen with boaters and ladies with parasols strolling along the seafront, or playing baseball and tennis on the Congress Hall's great law.
 But railroads changed all that. Newport, the Hamptons and Atlantic City began to draw the crowds. By the 1960s, the city had declined, and the Congress Hall was no exception: it had been taken over as a retreat and Bible study institute by Carl McIntire, a fire-breathing radio evangelist who became famous for broadcasting his ''Radio Free America'' program from a ship off the coast of New Jersey. When he was not thumping Satan and Communism over the airwaves, Rev. McIntire was a preservationist, buying up buildings like the Congress Hall and the even larger Admiral Hotel and decorating with bits of Americana like cannons or the anchor to a sunken galleon.
 Curtis Bashaw, one of the reverend's grandchildren, practically grew up in Congress Hall, absorbing its sense of history and design. ''It was like Eloise at the Plaza,'' he said. 
 He was expected to follow his grandfather into the ministry, and attended Wheaton College, a Christian school in Illinois. Two years was enough to persuade him to pursue law instead. 
 Then, in his senior year, his grandfather called, asking him to return and take over the Congress Hall.
 ''I kept deferring law school,'' Mr. Bashaw said, ''and I just fell in here.''
 ''Just falling in'' involved buying another old boarding house in the neighborhood, in 1986. With support from his father, a successful lawyer in Princeton, and his brother-in-law, he refurbished the building, reopening it as the Virginia Hotel. 
 ''The Virginia was closed and had been condemned for 15 years,'' said Tom Carroll, owner of the Mainstay hotel nearby. ''Ninety-nine percent of developers would have said, 'Tear it down and start from scratch,' but Curtis took the tougher approach.''
 About the time Mr. Bashaw became deeply involved in the Virginia project, his grandfather's finances were deteriorating. By the 1990's the bible institute was facing bankruptcy. Its two big hotels, the Congress Hall and the Admiral, went on the auction block. Both were in bad shape. Congress Hall was old and sagging, with cramped rooms and shaky plumbing. The roof leaked, the wiring was ancient, and the only air-conditioning was a few ceiling fans. The Admiral was even worse off. 
 After showing the buildings to dozens of potential buyers, Mr. Bashaw feared they would be torn down. Rather than let that happen, he gathered a group of investors and created a controversial financing plan: Realizing that he could not save both structures, he proposed to demolish the Admiral, sell the land for housing and use the money to refurbish Congress Hall.
 ''Everyone gave us heat,'' Mr. Bashaw said. ''The city wanted to save the Admiral, but they did not want to give up their $85,000 a year in property taxes.'' 
 Preservationists have since said the destruction of the building was a disaster, but Mr. Bashaw argues that it would have cost $45 million to restore the old hotel -- far more than he and his partners could have raised. In fact, he says, it was only by selling the land under the building that he managed to raise enough to afford the $20 million refurbishment of Congress Hall. 
 ''The old Admiral was a mistake when they built it,'' said Mr. Carroll, who is a former chairman of the New Jersey Historic Trust. ''It failed five times as a hotel, and its only success was when it was used a hospital during the war.'' 
 Yet the decision to demolish the Admiral still haunts Mr. Bashaw, in large part because its destruction hurt his grandfather, who died in 2002. Mr. Bashaw likened the demolition to losing a relative. 
 ''They tore it down, bit by bit,'' he said. 
 The Congress Hall was a much happier story. Mr. Bashaw and his partners began renovation of the Congress Hall in 2000, setting out to modernize without losing the historic feel of the place. More than 16,800 slate tiles were shaped and added to the leaking roof; aging cedar posts at the center of the hotel's dramatic columns were reinforced with pressure-treated support beams, and the entire wooden ballroom floor was carefully pulled up, refurbished and replaced. Mr. Bashaw also retained most of the original fixtures, from hall lights to wooden room doors.
 ''It looks like an old building, but it is an old building with modern amenities,'' said Luciano Corea, the Cape May city manager. ''It was an outstanding job.''
 The project had its detractors. A group of neighbors sued, on the ground that Mr. Bashaw was not following proper procedures under federal historic preservation rules. Neighbors also objected to his decision to pave part of the building's lawn and use it for hotel parking. 
 ''That lawn is one of the gems of Cape May,'' said George Lesser, an opponent who owns a house across the street from the hotel. ''We thought there were better uses rather than as a parking lot.''
 While describing himself as a supporter of the renovation, Mr. Lesser criticized Mr. Bashaw's decision to use architectural elements from the Admiral as part of the new Congress Hall.
 ''The people who built the Admiral hated the Congress Hall, they are diametrically opposed styles,'' Mr. Lesser said. ''To take pieces of one and smash them into the other shows a lack of sensitivity.''
 Mr. Bashaw's response is that the approach allowed him to preserve part of an otherwise lost structure. The Admiral's wrought-iron staircase, for instance, now connects two floors of Congress Hall.
 Mr. Bashaw recently added a third business, the Star motel, to his holdings in Cape May. If the Virginia is designed to be snug and cozy, and the Congress Hall magnificent and historic, the Star, with flat-screen televisions and bright pastel colors, is supposed to be fun and accessible for families. Mr. Bashaw says he thinks of the Congress Hall as the grand dame of Cape May, and the Star as ''the frisky little cousin.''
 The Congress Hall renovation sparked a larger debate within Cape May, on whether to remain a sleepy hamlet or become a tourist destination. People like Mr. Lesser argued that the city was in danger of losing its character by trying to attract tourists at the expense of residents.
 ''One could argue that what Curtis Bashaw has been trying to do over the years is make Cape May more like Atlantic City,'' Mr. Lesser said. ''A lot of people in Cape May would really be delighted if they could tear down the Victorian piles and build Trump-type hotels along the beach.''
 But Mr. Bashaw's supporters argue that projects like the Congress Hall renovation are the only way to save the historic structures that the preservationists love. They say a slow decline is no future.
 ''It was outstanding,'' said Mr. Corea, the town manager, of the renovation. ''That hotel has revitalized the area.''
 The question now is, can Mr. Bashaw work the same magic on the impoverished pockets of Atlantic City? 
 He says he is eager to get to work. On April 1 he intends to begin by scheduling rounds of meetings with city leaders and casino executives to get a feel for what needs to be done.
 His own view of his mission: ''To help make Atlantic City a nice place to live and a nice place to visit, the way it was in the 1920's.''
 Or, in other words, ''to seize the title again of being America's playground.''

HEADLINE: Just One of the Guys, Under Investigation

BYLINE: By David Kocieniewski. 
David Kocieniewski is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
As he rose from the obscurity of Middlesex County politics to the throne of New Jersey government, Governor McGreevey's most valuable asset was his unfailing ability to play the ''just one of da guys'' card.
 Challenging the genteel Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, Mr. McGreevey focused on economic issues that squeezed the middle class -- property taxes and auto insurance -- in a plainspoken style that sounded like echoes from a Bayonne diner. Mrs. Whitman narrowly won re-election, and had left office before Mr. McGreevey's next run for governor in 2001, but that didn't stop ''Jim from Carteret'' from painting the entire Republican Party in the same gilded hues. 
 One of the most effective McGreevey campaign ads that year featured the aspiring governor in a bomber jacket, driving a car over the Pulaski Skyway (the acropolis of smokestacks and closed factories in the background), criticizing Republicans with a street-corner put-down: ''Hey guys, you blew a precious opportunity.''
 Given Mr. McGreevey's unrelenting attempts to identify himself with New Jersey's gritty, struggling classes, it should come as little surprise that his political fate may now hinge on his relationship with a waste management executive. No, this is not ''The Sopranos'' (and there has never been any suggestion that the waste management executive in question, David D'Amiano, has the slightest bit of involvement with organized crime), but the federal investigation into the McGreevey administration's dealings with Mr. D'Amiano appear likely to dominate -- and perhaps transform -- state politics in the next year.
 Federal agents recently subpoenaed records from the governor's office, state Democratic headquarters and the treasurer's office, and are trying to determine whether Mr. D'Amiano, a McGreevey fund-raiser, got favors in exchange for donations. Investigators also subpoenaed records from the state Department of Agriculture, and are reportedly examining whether the governor or any aides interceded in a land dispute on behalf of a contributor drummed up by Mr. D'Amiano.
 Mr. McGreevey and his aides insist that no one in the administration did anything improper. But there are unmistakable signs that all sides are bracing for a vicious legal and political battle. It is unclear what evidence United States Attorney Christopher Christie's investigators have gathered, but it was enough to persuade a federal judge to authorize a search warrant for the office of a sitting governor. Mr. Christie, who is often mentioned as a Republican candidate for governor next year, is savvy enough to realize that it would be politically disastrous to conduct such a high-profile raid if it turned out to be a smear attempt.
 Meanwhile Mr. McGreevey, the state committee and two of his top aides -- Kevin Hagan and Amy Mansue -- have lined up high-priced, high-powered legal teams to defend them from any fallout from the investigation.
 Despite those rather ominous signals, many Democrats say it is far too early to panic. The high cost of political advertising on television forces nearly every campaign to scrounge for cash in uncomfortable places, so it is not unusual for a scrupulous candidate to have a handful of unsavory characters among his fund-raisers.
 If the federal investigation relied on unethical cooperating witnesses but failed to make a convincing case against any members of the McGreevey administration, the United States attorney's office could conceivably end up the villain of the entire episode. Just last year, Mayor John Street of Philadelphia's struggling re-election campaign was rocked by the news that the F.B.I. had bugged his office, and the revelation brought such a surge of sympathy that he cruised to re-election.
 But the most worrisome development for the McGreevey administration are reports that some of the figures involved in the investigation were wearing concealed recording devices, taping conversations with political officials. Bismarck, who once cautioned that anyone who liked laws or sausages should not watch them being made, would almost certainly be appalled to see the spectacularly unseemly way modern campaign contributions are solicited -- even legitimate contributions.
 Even before the D'Amiano investigation began generating ugly headlines, the administration had been dogged by three different fund-raising inquiries involving Mr. McGreevey's compatriots from his days as mayor of Woodbridge. If this case revealed that the administration did indeed deliver political favors, Mr. McGreevey, who faces re-election next year, could see his sagging poll numbers drop even more.
 Mr. McGreevey's communications director, Cathy Ellis, brushed aside suggestions that his associates from North Jersey had caused him an inordinate amount of political torment. She also predicted that, in the end, the facts will prove that the McGreevey administration upheld the highest ethical standards.
 ''What will be shown is that there's no there there,'' she said.
 Whatever the investigation ultimately unearths, it has already demonstrated that in a state like New Jersey, where municipal government is a blood sport, political loyalty can carry a very high price. The kind of scrappy operatives who help fight local political battles don't always stand up to the glare of statewide scrutiny. And if an officeholder isn't careful about his associates from the old neighborhood, he runs the risk of being sent back to that neighborhood far sooner than he might have wished.

HEADLINE: Lasting Discord Clouds Talks On North Korean Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
Almost two weeks after North Korea agreed to new, supposedly more intimate ''working groups'' to discuss its nuclear weapons program, Bush administration officials say that the agenda for the talks remains unclear and that the discussions may not occur until April or May.
 The idea of trying to resolve disagreements over North Korea's nuclear programs in one or more working groups came up in the last round of talks in Beijing at the end of February. Besides the United States and North Korea, Russia, China, South Korea and Japan took part.
 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said afterward that he was ''quite satisfied'' with how they went and that the working groups established ''an institutionalized process to move forward in further discussions.'' 
 The objective, according to administration officials, is to create an unpressured atmosphere in which North Korea may feel more free to negotiate steps toward the American demand for a ''complete, verifiable and irreversible dismantlement'' of its nuclear programs.
 But there is dissent in the administration over how much the talks with North Korea accomplished and whether the working groups will produce further progress. ''The premise is wrong,'' said an American official. ''If the North Koreans are not willing to show flexibility at a high level, they're not going to let their munchkins do the job.''
 The framework of the Bush administration's approach is to insist on an upfront pledge by North Korea to dismantle its programs, and then to grant benefits -- from security guarantees to economic and energy assistance -- in return for step-by-step progress toward that goal.
 Hard-liners in the administration say the main disappointment of the most recent talks was the failure to get a commitment on the dismantling of the weapons. Those who favor a more conciliatory approach say the main accomplishment was to get all the other participants in the talks to agree that North Korea must commit itself to that goal.
 A top administration official described the proceedings as ''grueling'' and said that even minor progress was a real victory. ''The consensus among us is that this is a ground game,'' he said, using a football metaphor. ''We're going to move the ball five yards at a time.''
 American and Asian diplomats said the biggest disappointment occurred because of a last-minute snag on the last day of the talks in Beijing, when the six nations could not agree to a statement committing themselves to the working groups format.
 North Korea, several diplomats said, came in with a last-minute demand that the final statement include a reference to its disagreement on fundamental issues with Washington, viewed by the American delegation as a step backward. In the absence of a joint statement, Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing of China announced a consensus for working groups on his own.
 An Asian diplomat said the Chinese delegates were ''very, very disappointed and probably annoyed'' over North Korea's move. An American official described Mr. Li and other Chinese officials as furious.
 Another clash at the meetings occurred over the American insistence that North Korea acknowledge not only its plutonium program but also its efforts to make a nuclear bomb with highly enriched uranium. North Korea has acknowledged the first method but not the second.
 The leader of the American delegation, James A. Kelly, an assistant secretary of state, recalled at a recent Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing that the North Korean delegate demanded proof it had a uranium enrichment program. Mr. Kelly said he replied, ''If I were to give you all that information, it might make it easier for you to conceal it.''
 Administration officials said Mr. Bush had telephoned President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea in February to make sure his delegates would offer energy assistance to the North only in return for an upfront commitment on disarmament. In the end, the offer was transmitted in exactly the fashion that Mr. Bush wanted, an administration official said, adding, ''That was huge.''
 Another major victory tallied by administration officials had to do with China more than North Korea. Many American officials say that they were elated that China had basically endorsed the American approach and that the five parties were lined up against North Korea.
 ''I'll be frank,'' the American official said. ''The Chinese and Russians would like us to give more goodies, but now they're pushing the North Koreans in the direction we want. Those are things we've never had before.''

HEADLINE: Bargains Draw Visitors To Bustling Buenos Aires

BYLINE: By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
BULLDOZERS and cranes vie with limousines these days on the Avenida Alvear, in Buenos Aires's ritzy Recoleta neighborhood, as construction workers race to transform one of the Argentine capital's most elegant palaces into the exclusive wing of a new 180-room Hyatt hotel.
 The refurbishment of the residence of the Duhau family dating from the 1930's will cost $60 million and is scheduled to open in the spring of 2005. According to Roberto Ferrari, the project's coordinator, it ''will be sophisticated and glamorous.''
 Argentina might still be on its economic sickbed, recovering from four years of bitter recession, but its woes -- and particularly the sharp drop in the value of the peso -- have been a boon to foreign tourists. 
 Millions of them -- Americans, Brazilians, Spaniards, Italians and Germans -- are flocking to this, ''the Paris of South America,'' to sample its tango, and its abundant museums, sophisticated restaurants and great shopping, at bargain prices.
 According to a study published recently by the city's economic development office, Cedem, three million foreign tourists visited Buenos Aires last year, some 50 percent more than in 2002. In the first quarter of 2004 alone, about 1.5 million visitors are expected. For nearly 10 years until early 2002, the peso had been pegged to the dollar at parity, meaning dinner at Sucre, one of the capital's toniest restaurants, used to cost $75 a head with wine. A room at a midrange hotel such as a Holiday Inn would typically cost nearly $200 a night.
 Today, with the Argentine currency now trading at just under 3 to the dollar, a dinner for two with wine at Sucre should cost well under $50. A midrange hotel, such as the Lancaster on the Avenida Cordoba, can cost as little as $45 a night, about half the price before devaluation, while a room at the Holiday Inn Express can cost as little as $85. A double at the elegant Marriott Plaza on the Plaza San Martin costs just over $100.
 Rates for Argentines at cheaper hotels can be even lower; otherwise, hotel managers argue, they would have no local clients. But Arturo Garcia Rosa, president of HVS, hotel consultants in Argentina, and other tourism professionals advise against haggling for the rates charged to locals. Bargaining doesn't normally work, unless you are staying for a month or so. 
 ''Rates in general are dramatically lower,'' said Mr. Garcia Rosa. ''Four-star hotels are half the price they used to be and are about $100 a night cheaper than in most main capitals.''
 While the new Hyatt's rooms -- at $300 a night -- will be far from cheap, Mr. Ferrari says he is counting on increasing demand: occupancy rates in the city, even at the most expensive five-star hotels, are over 75 percent, more than double what they were in the depths of the 2001 crisis.
 Hotel development is not limited to the new Hyatt. Another luxury hotel, run by Sofitel, the French chain, has recently opened in the Recoleta district, while the Alvear Palace, long the capital's best-known luxury hotel, is refurbishing some of its rooms to meet demand. And restaurants are taking heart from the boom and expanding. Last year Orient Express Hotels opened La Cabana, a faithful re-creation of one of the city's most celebrated establishments, on Rodriguez Pena. The original, patronized by figures such as Eva Peron, Richard M. Nixon and the Aga Khan, closed in 1996 as Argentina slid into financial crisis. 
 ''The devaluation changed the scenario overnight,'' said Lucas Rentero, co-founder of Eternautas, a Buenos Aires operator offering private tours in several languages focusing on the capital's history and culture.
 For two years after February 1999, when Mr. Rentero and his two partners set up Eternautas, they personally guided two or three tours a week. Today, the partners, plus a team of 10 multilingual guides, take out as many as seven tours a day.
 ''Our prices are down by 30 or 40 percent,'' said Mr. Rentero, explaining that some of the currency gains have been eaten away by inflation. ''But we still charge only half the price you would pay for a private guide in a European capital.'' A half-day tour for two people with car, driver and English-speaking guide currently costs $62. For a group of 10, the price is $14 a head.
 ''I just fell in love with the place,'' said Judy Milliken, a retired travel agent from St. Petersburg, Fla., who took Eternautas's Evita tour in November. ''I just loved the architecture, the tango, Evita, the cafe culture, the great food -- and where else can you get a great bottle of wine for $4? It's terribly inexpensive.''
 So what are the best buys? Because prices of imports have risen as a result of devaluation, ''made in Argentina'' is back in fashion. On the Calle Florida, the city's main shopping street, lots of new talabarterias -- stores selling handmade leather and silver goods -- have sprung up. Shops specializing in indigenous arts and crafts, such as Pueblo Indio in the San Telmo district or Arte Etnico Argentino in Palermo Viejo, offer colorful blankets and rugs, ethnic furniture, masks and sculptures.
 Another good buy is Argentine wine, which is beginning to gain recognition. Jaime Chmea, partner at the Winery on the Avenida Leandro N. Alem, who has increased the wine store-restaurants in his chain from two to five in the past 18 months and is about to open another next to the dockside Hilton, says prices of top vintages in dollars have risen to precrisis levels, but that most wines are still a bargain.
 A Malbec from the vinyards of Escorihuela Gascon, a local favorite, costs about $10, while an Angelica Zapata Malbec, which sells for $60 in New York, costs $35 here.
 ''In January 2002, I can tell you business was depressed and I was depressed,'' said Mr. Chmea, ''but not anymore!''

HEADLINE: The Incredible Shrinking Dollar

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL. 
ALAN COWELL is a correspondent for The Times based in London.

 BODY:
EARLY last year, an American arriving in Europe might have reckoned that a dollar exchanged for pounds or euros might just suffice to buy a newspaper or maybe, in some places, a coffee. Twelve months later, don't be so sure.
 Over the last year the dollar has fallen by between one-fifth and one-quarter against both currencies. In February, it reached its lowest level in 12 years against the British pound and dropped to its weakest level against the euro since the European Union's common currency was introduced on the international money markets in 1999. 
 In mid-February, the euro touched $1.28, compared to $1.05 in March 2003, while the pound hit $1.90 compared to $1.55 in April 2003. And those were just the official rates for trading on the currency markets -- not the far less generous rates used in exchange booths or credit card transactions, which can be 10 percent more expensive.
 Some Americans reported paying over $2 for a pound in London, and the idea of one-to-one parity between the dollar and the euro -- last recorded in November 2002 -- became no more than a wistful memory. At those inflated rates, a Starbucks frappucino would come in at over $6.50 and, in London, only Britain's racy tabloids cost less than $1. Sending an airmail postcard from Rome to the United States costs $1.80; a Caesar salad at the Adlon Hotel in Berlin is now $16; and in Paris, a silk scarf from Hermes comes in at $310. It's hardly surprising, then, that hoteliers and others say the number of Americans, once viewed as the kingpins among tourists in Europe, is down sharply. 
 ''Americans don't want to travel any more,'' said Jean-Louis Descoins, manager of the Hotel Bel Ami in the St.-Germain-des- Pres district of Paris. ''There was a little revival after the end of the Iraq war but now with the fall of the dollar everything is stagnant.''
 The fall in the dollar, moreover, is only the latest in a series of setbacks. American tourism had barely begun to rebound from the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, when the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq and the campaign against terrorism deterred foreign travel. 
 ''There is definitely a shortage of American visitors,'' said Bob Barton, a spokesman for Visit Britain, an official body promoting foreign tourism. ''Some of it is still connected to concerns about security. American visitors are noticeable by their absence and the exchange rate isn't helping.''
 Yet, in conversations with Americans in London, Paris and Rome, some visitors seemed to have drawn on a doughty resolve in the face of adversity.
 Hotel discounts and low air fares have persuaded some Americans to come to Europe. Some had booked vacations at more favorable, locked-in prices. Many Americans said they were spending less, avoiding stores and eating cheaply. 
 ''There are a lot of food emporiums near our hotel and we just buy food and a bottle of wine and take it back to the hotel,'' said Renee Margulies, from Philadelphia, who is visiting London with her husband, Milton. The couple, who are retired, talked to a reporter in a tourism office in Regent Street, where she said London ''is costing us 25 to 30 percent more than last year, and it's sort of a shock.''
 On the south bank of the River Thames, at the London Eye Ferris wheel (which now costs $22 for an adult ticket), Colleen Kerr, an education administrator from Denver, said she and a colleague, Amy Weed, planned their trip to London when the exchange rate stood at $1.75 to the pound last year. When she arrived in London in February, the exchange rate at Heathrow Airport -- admittedly, airports are not known for attractive exchange rates -- was a staggering $2.09. ''We are having to be very careful,'' she said.
 Some people have been put off though, particularly by airline security scares, said Monica Barrington, who runs Uptown Reservations, an upscale bed-and-breakfast agency based in London. ''Not only have you got the exchange rate, you've got the planes being grounded.''
 Those worries echo in France.
 In Paris, the Tourism Office says, the number of American visitors fell by 26 percent, to 3,135,600 between January and November 2003 compared to the same period in 2002. Part of the decline reflects American resentment of French opposition to the war in Iraq, according to some visitors. ''There's a backlash against France, a big backlash,'' said Mr. Margulies. 
 Some hoteliers believe fear of terrorism is keeping Americans at home. Pascal Gimel, manager of the D'Aubusson hotel in the St.-Germain area said Americans were once 75 percent of its guests, but that share had fallen by half since Al Qaeda's attacks on American targets. ''We did a promotion offering 1 euro for 1 dollar,'' he said. ''But we still haven't recovered from Sept. 11.''
 The constraints on hoteliers and tour operators seem to have offered some compensations. Strolling along the Champs-Elysees, Nancy Crow, 33, a real-estate agent from Milwaukee said: ''I don't know if the dollar has something to do with it, but the French are much more friendly this time than they were two years ago.'' 
 In February, the tour operator Contiki, based in Anaheim, Calif., which arranges escorted European tours for 18- to 35-year-olds, and the Royal Scotsman, which runs luxury train trips in Scotland -- ranging from $990 a person for a one-night trip to $7,590 for a seven-night tour -- offered guarantees that vacations priced in dollars would not be affected by currency fluctuations. 
 Not everyone sees those silver linings, particularly in Italy where the weakness of the dollar has compounded price increases introduced stealthily by many restaurants and cafe owners when the euro replaced the lira. Jon R. Snyder, director of the Rome Studies Center of the University of California, suggested that different Americans felt the squeeze in different ways. In particular, he pointed to the impact on Californians studying in Italy.
 ''Basically it's a triple whammy,'' he said. ''You have the dollar's total collapse, and then on top of that you have the changeover from lira to euro, which has added an enormous amount to prices, and third you have the economic crisis in California.'' 
 ''Some of the students here have real economic difficulties,'' he said. ''They get their financial aid, but it's in dollars. They end up having to choose between a coffee at the cafe or sending a postcard home. They are really feeling the pinch.''

HEADLINE: A Tale of Two Indias (and Americas)

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 While no one should begrudge Indians and others in the developing world their opportunity to take advantage of the benefits of modernization, their success is not due solely to ''good timing, hard work, talent and luck'' (column, March 11).
 The export of thousands of jobs overseas since the 1970's has more to do with specific United States economic policies, particularly free trade and deregulation, that have resulted domestically in corporations and wealthy individuals increasing their fortunes and the standard of living of American workers remaining stagnant.
 The effect is much like the recent economic ''recovery.'' The rising stock market indicates that someone is doing well, but the vast majority of ordinary people never see the money ''trickle down.''

CHRIS PEDLER
Portsmouth, N.H., March 11, 2004


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: A $713 Ashtray Built on Landfill

BYLINE: By Jessica Bruder

 BODY:
Of course, if a person must smoke, it's a good idea to have an ashtray, and the officials at the Cumberland County Improvement Authority have the most stylish one in New Jersey. 
 How can you tell? Because they paid $713 for it.
 Adorning the entrance to the authority's office in Millville, the receptacle is made of Florentine marble. On Tuesday Louis Magazzu, a town freeholder, held a news conference denouncing the authority's purchases, which also include a dozen executive chairs ($1,752 each), a fancy lectern ($1,232) and 50 wooden stacking chairs ($359 each). He argued that it was out of place for the authority, which is responsible for managing the county dump, to boast such luxurious appointments. 
 ''Whenever you work for a public entity, you need to have a nice public presentation,'' he said, ''but you don't need to make the place look like one of Saddam Hussein's palaces. They literally built this palace on the landfill of Cumberland County.'' Mr. Magazzu added that the spending seemed particularly reckless in light of the fact that Cumberland is one of New Jersey's poorest counties. 
 Steven Wymbs of the improvement authority countered that it had aided the local economy to the tune of $20 million over the last 10 years, largely by maintaining the lowest waste disposal fees in the state. He also argued that the fixtures had been ordered to match the building that houses the authority.
 ''The furniture purchases were dictated by the age and design of the structure,'' Mr. Wymbs said. ''It's a neoclassical structure made of marble and decorative block with brass doors and ornate ironwork.''
 And the ashtray? ''The trash receptacle is designed and made from materials that complement not only the structure it stands in front of, but the ambiance that the city of Millville is trying to portray.'' Jessica Bruder

HEADLINE: Phillies Hope Reality Matches Expectations

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla. 

 BODY:
LARRY BOWA was not manager of the year last season, but credit him with making the most perceptive and realistic comment of the year.
 ''I thought the Mets on paper were going to blow away this division,'' he said about the 2002 Mets in spring training last year. ''Guys have to go out and do it. We can sit here and talk about how good our team is, but until you go out and do it, we're just like everyone else.''
 Bowa was responding to a question about the status of the team he managed, the Philadelphia Phillies, as National League East favorites with the addition of Jim Thome, David Bell and Kevin Millwood. Bowa cited those 2002 Mets as a reason not to get too excited too soon. Despite the addition of Mo Vaughn, Roberto Alomar, Jeromy Burnitz and Roger Cedeno, the Mets finished last instead of first, as expected. 
 Bowa was smart enough not to get excited prematurely, and his wisdom finished ahead of his managing. The Phillies, with all of their promising additions, finished third. Now they have made some more promising moves and again are viewed as a likely division winner. 
 ''Everything on paper looks good,'' he said. ''But you have to go out and do it. You can't talk about it. We haven't done anything yet.''
 This winter the Phillies added Eric Milton to their starting rotation and reconstructed their bullpen with Billy Wagner, one of the league's best closers; Tim Worrell, who was an outstanding substitute for Robb Nen, San Francisco's injured closer; and Roberto Hernandez.
 What happened last year to undermine the Phillies' plans for winning the division championship? Thome, after all, did his part, hitting a league-leading 47 home runs and driving in 131 runs.
 ''We blew 18 saves, and I didn't have a closer the second half,'' Bowa said. ''Polanco missed five weeks, Burrell hit .200 and Bell missed half a season. Those were the four things that happened. They aren't excuses, just reality.''
 The injuries to Bell and Placido Polanco were what Bowa had mentioned, talking about this year's chances, he said, ''Obviously, you have to stay healthy.''
 But the season has not started, and the Phillies are not healthy. Thome and Wagner sustained finger injuries early in spring training, and Bell, who was limited to 85 games last season, hurt his right shoulder during batting practice on Friday.
 Aside from injuries, the Phillies have to avoid performances like that of Pat Burrell, the left fielder, who batted .209 and drove in 64 runs after having knocked in 116 with a .282 batting average the year before.
 ''We hope that last year was just an off year,'' Bowa said. ''He's been down here since the first of February working hard. It's just a matter of him feeling comfortable and getting back that positive attitude.''
 Burrell displayed a gruff attitude when he was asked about his 2003 performance. ''I'm not talking about last year,'' he said.
 But Burrell's performance was an integral part of what Mike Lieberthal, the Phillies' catcher, called ''a definitely disappointing'' season.
 ''We went through that midseason crash where we lost 9 of 10 or 10 of 11, which killed us,'' Lieberthal said. ''And the Marlins beat us up all season. But it still came down to the last week of the season.''
 He was talking about the wild-card race, and the Phillies lost that one, too.
 But Lieberthal, not to mention other members of the Phillies, believes the team is better this year. ''We look stronger on paper,'' he said. ''We'll probably have higher expectations because we'll probably be picked to win the division.'' The Phillies, though, should remember that the Mets did not win the next year, either.

All Around the Horn
 Mike Mussina of the Yankees and David McCarty of the Boston Red Sox were teammates on the Stanford baseball team and classmates in the university's economics department. Both could be major league pitchers.
 Mussina has served in that role for 13 years. McCarty is only getting started.
 ''I think it's something I can do,'' said McCarty, who has been an outfielder-first baseman for six years in the majors. ''Especially with a utility player, it adds a lot of value. It's like having a 26th man. You can pitch a couple innings when the bullpen is beat up or when you need some mop-up duty.''
 McCarty, 34, pitched in high school but not at Stanford, where he was a year behind Mussina. ''We had too many good pitchers there,'' McCarty said.
 He was inspired to try double duty in the majors when Brooks Kieschnick did it for Milwaukee last season. Kieschnick batted .300 in 70 games and compiled a 1-1 record and a 5.26 earned run average in 42 relief appearances for the Brewers.
 ''I talked to him last night,'' McCarty said the other day. ''It was kind of reassuring to see that he went through the same things that I'm going through -- the fatigue, the way you have to budget your time and manage everything, make sure you get ground balls, fly balls, hitting, pitching. There's a lot of work you have to get in in a limited amount of time and certainly energy, too.''
 Last week, the Red Sox decided that double duty was affecting McCarty's first role -- hitting and fielding -- so they cut back his pitching to one game a week with the rest of his work on the side.
 ''We're not abandoning him,'' Manager Terry Francona said. ''We want to work some side days in more and keep him on limited games so physically he can have a chance to do some things in the field a little bit more. Right now it's important for him to play the field, play left field, right field, first base and feel his body. It's very difficult what he's trying to do.''
 McCarty said pitching could detract from his other work ''if the wear and tear is too much.''
 ''That's why we're going to back off the pitching a little bit because my hitting stroke hasn't come around to where it should be at this point,'' he said. ''The wear and tear of trying to keep up with the pitchers and keep up with the hitters is just too much at this point.''
 But McCarty remains optimistic that he can achieve his dual goal.
 ''So far so good,'' he said. ''If nothing else I've shown I can get big-league hitters out. I don't need to be the guy you go to in the seventh or eighth innings to get a big out. That's not what this is about. Just the fact that I can go out and do it is something of value.''

Steroids and the Grassy Knoll
 Maybe they have been on steroids too long, but the conspiracy theorists are in full bloom. Gary Sheffield's thumb injury? Barry Bonds's back ailment?
 If those sluggers have been steroids users in the past, as has been widely speculated, but they do not do their usual amount of slugging this year, suspicious minds posit, they can attribute their decline to their injuries.
 Now about the condition of Jason Giambi's knee that was operated on. . . .
